—I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown;
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and

(ii) desertion for two years;

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I intend to give notice of intention to withdraw a notice of motion, but before doing so I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my statement to the Senate when giving notice of disallowance of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Regulations, the effect of these regulations is to continue in force a limitation imposed in the Schedule to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act on the rights of certain individuals to receive reasons for decisions on promotions, transfers and appeals in the Australian Public Service. At the time the notice was given, I indicated to the Senate that the Government was then considering the issue of giving reasons for promotion and transfer decisions within the context of new procedures contained in the Public Service Amendment Bill which is at present before the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has now advised of the Government's decision that amendments should be introduced to the Public Service Amendment Bill to make specific provision for giving, on request, information regarding decisions to promote or transfer individual officers to persons affected by those decisions. He further advised that a consequential amendment is proposed to be made to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, to be introduced at the same time, to exempt from the requirements of that Act decisions in respect of which information will be provided in accordance with the amendment to the Public Service Amendment Bill.

The Committee, having considered the advice, together with a detailed outline of the proposals, decided to seek an undertaking from the Government that the proposed amendments to the Public Service Amendment Bill and the proposed consequential amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act would be brought forward for debate in both Houses of Parliament during the present period of sittings. The Committee has now received a response from the Government to its request for the undertaking, but has not yet had an opportunity to consider it. The Committee has also received a further representation from the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association.

As this is the last day on which notice of disallowance may be resolved the Committee will be giving urgent consideration to the response later this day. For procedural reasons and to preserve the right of other senators to take over the notice if they wish, I now give notice, in accordance with Standing Order 109A, that it is my intention during the consideration of business later this day to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name and relating to the disallowance of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 274 and made under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. As this statement indicates, however, no decision has yet been made on whether to proceed with withdrawal. I also propose at placing of business to postpone consideration of the notice of disallowance to a later hour of the day to enable the Committee to conclude its deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank Senator Lewis for his courtesy in making the statement at the time he has. I am sure he will appreciate, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, that there are a number of issues involved which honourable senators would like to consider before the matter reaches the Senate for debate. So I ask , by way of interpolation in the statement I obtained leave to make, that a copy of Senator Lewis's statement be made available to all honourable senators, together with, if possible, a copy of the undertaking-if that is the appropriate expression-the Government has given to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, so that that also may be considered by honourable senators before the matter comes on for debate tonight.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in the Sydney Morning Herald relating to the Government's housing policy announced last week, and the allegation in that article that the Government's housing policy discriminates against people renting houses and does nothing to increase the amount of rental housing available? Does the Minister agree that the housing package announced by the Treasurer adds to the bias in a tax system which already 'encourages speculative property investment and discourages productive investment'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article referred to by Senator Button. I think it ought to be said that the housing package that was announced addressed itself to assisting those in the pursuit of home ownership. The package had a variety of measures within it. Part of it involved providing a rebate within the tax system for those in the early years of home purchase. Another part of the package was to means test the homes savings grant which assists in bridging the deposit gap that many people find. I suppose if people were to draw away from the matters that were addressed in that statement they could find other areas where assistance equally could be granted. The package that was produced addressed itself to assisting people in purchasing their homes . I think, in conjunction with the consultation with the banks and others, it was a very worthwhile package and was well received throughout Australia. If some other debate on aspects of the matter is necessary, perhaps we can have that at a more appropriate time. Suffice it to say in Question Time that I believe this package will be of great assistance to the many thousands of prospective and present home owners to whom it has been addressed.

—I ask a supplementary question. By implication at least I asked the Minister whether it was appreciated that in her own words, insofar as the policy assists those in pursuit of home ownership, this operates in fact as a positive disadvantage to those many thousands of people who cannot afford at this stage the pursuit of home ownership and who seek rental accommodation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I said, the policy addresses itself to those already in pursuit of owning their homes. It could be argued that there are other areas where assistance may be given. The priority in this particular package was given to assisting people to achieve the ownership of their own homes. The high percentage of home ownership and the objective of continuing that high percentage of home ownership throughout Australia were drawn out in many of the statements that were made. Home ownership was one of the principal factors in the way in which the Government did address the measures that we are now discussing.

ANSWER.PARA: I would not argue that if we want a more complete package we may have more funds that could be directed to welfare housing or we may have larger assistance directed to rent. There is a package that can be used in conjunction with State governments in emergency or crisis situations to give assistance. The package, as it was presented, was comprehensive in a number of ways. Let us not argue about what was not done but rather let us look at the positive assistance that that package will be able to give.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of allegations made last week on Sydney television Channel 7 that nuclear weapons research was being carried out at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's establishment at Lucas Heights and that strontium-90, an isotope appearing from weapons tests, has been detected in the vicinity of Lucas Heights which has holdings of weapons material? Are these allegations correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was advised of such a program and of such allegations . I made a statement on the matter because, frankly, I am at a loss to understand the suggestion that the Atomic Energy Commission may be engaged in nuclear weapons research. This is a perennial allegation and it is totally without fact. As a party to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, Australia has entered into a solemn international commitment not to engage in such activities. Compliance with the treaty is verified through the system of international safeguards established by the International Atomic Energy Agency. In fact last week, at the time when the allegations apparently were made, International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards inspectors completed an inspection of Lucas Heights. Although they have not yet had time to lodge their official report, I am advised that they were satisfied that Australia is complying with the non- proliferation obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: A claim was also made that there have been a number of radioactive emissions from Lucas Heights, particularly strontium-90, but because there have been no public health surveys over the past 25 years the effect of these emissions is not known. In fact, the Atomic Energy Commission regularly monitors emissions from Lucas Heights. New South Wales health authorities have examined the Commission's monitoring methods and are satisfied with them. The Commission's activities do not release strontium-90 to the atmosphere in quantities sufficient to be detectable against background fallout due to weapons tests. The Australian Radiation Laboratory carries out a national program of monitoring strontium-90 levels and has advised that strontium-90 levels in the Lucas Heights environment are consistent with levels found elsewhere throughout Australia and known to have arisen entirely from atmospheric nuclear weapons tests. I do hope that such unfounded allegations are not made. There is no basis for them at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Is it a fact that computer tapes from his Department containing the records of unemployment benefit beneficiaries have been provided to the Australian Taxation Office for the purpose of comparing records and conducting surveys? While I am aware that there is provision for the exchange of information between his Department and the Taxation Office, the legislation covering this was drawn up in the pre- computer era and refers to individual information, as do the manuals of his Department drawing up rules of conduct in such cases. Will the Minister inform the Senate what protection is being provided for those who are on either his Department's tapes or the Taxation Office's tapes? Will he make a statement as to the intent and extent of this practice if it is, in fact, occurring?

—I have no advice on what action has been taken between my Department and the Taxation Office with respect to the matter raised by Senator Grimes. There is nothing exceptional in that, on the assumption which is part of the question-that if that has been occurring it is within the law and action which is permitted to be taken between the two departments. I will, however, examine the matter which Senator Grimes has raised and see whether some public statement should be made on it. My only qualification to an immediate agreement to the request which Senator Grimes has made is that, to some extent, one does not always want to disclose measures which are taken to prevent abuse. I need to examine the matter from that point of view. I will ensure that the practice is explained to me in some detail and I will examine Senator Grimes's question in that light.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question arising out of Senator Chaney's answer. I was concerned when he said that there would be nothing exceptional in such a practice taking place without the Minister's knowledge. I put it to the Minister that indeed it would be exceptional if there were such a general exchange of confidential information from computerised records of people 's personal details without the Minister being consulted or without his knowledge. Will he reconsider his answer and reconsider whether such practices really should occur without his knowledge?
—That really is not a question at all; it is a series of assumptions which are aimed at me. I will see whether there is any basis in fact for the assumptions Senator Grimes is making.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to an article in the Courier-Mail of yesterday's date which states that an application by the Fitzroy Association of Racing Toads based in Rockhampton to participate in the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane has been rejected. I might add that I was approached by a member of this association at the Rockhampton Airport yesterday. That member asked me to make strong representations on this case. It appears that the General Manager of the Commonwealth Games, Mr Whitehead, acknowledges that if the Games were to be held in a leap year the application for toad racing may have been more successful. Traditionally this ethnic group has suffered blatant prejudice at the hands of homo sapiens and, as unwilling migrants to our country, they do not have a leg to leap on. Also being provincially based offers little opportunity for their chorus of voices to be effectively heard in the capital cities.
—I suggest that the honourable senator ask his question soon. He is giving a lot of information.

—Can the Minister assure the Fitzroy Association of Racing Toads that consideration will be given to this almost silent majority in Queensland? Can the decision be reversed so as to give racing toads a chance to be represented and take a giant leap with mankind? This would enable members of this rejected amphibian group, with their warts and all, to do something creative before they croak it.

—I can remember that in Laura in north Queensland the shower block associated with the local hotel had a space at the bottom through which the local toads could hop and join any visitors such as Senate committee members who were in Laura examining Aboriginal conditions. Senator Bonner will remember that. I have no knowledge about the organisation at Rockhampton, the Fitzroy Association of Racing Toads. I am reminded of another organisation in Queensland coming from the town of Eulo, where every year lizard races are held. One might wonder whether the lizard races of Eulo would be a better event for the Commonwealth Games. In any event if it is possible to have Australian national football as a sport at some Commonwealth Games I am sure that any kind of unnatural sporting activity could be undertaken. Whilst one might say that the organisers of the Games might be hardliners or that they might be definite, assertive or authoritarian in their views, one could never say that they were toadies.

As I understand it, the whole speech may have been addressed in the context of the Industries Assistance Commission review of assistance to industry. I think it is known that at present we are receiving deputations from a number of industry groups in the pre-Budget consultation process. However, I do not wish to make any comment on what may have been said by my colleague Sir Phillip Lynch in his speech because it is not the practice in a pre-Budget situation to canvass alternative proposals, but perhaps I should say this: At this stage there is no proposal before the Government with regard to changes in the corporate tax rate, although I presume that by the time we complete the Budget process almost every suggestion imaginable will have been put before us by people either outside or within government. I am aware of figures which show that there will be an increase in the collections of personal income tax. I would think that as we are in this pre-Budget context it remains for me just to say that I do not speculate on any changes in either company tax or personal tax that will result from Budget deliberations but that the Government is receiving many representations in both areas at present.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is about the suppression of worship by the Soviet Union in Lithuania. Is it a fact that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace, located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, and the only church in that country built since World War II, was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August 1960 and subsequently confiscated in 1961? Will the Minister make representations to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for the Church of Mary Queen of Peace to be restored to the people of Klaipeda, Lithuania, for religious worship so that they can exercise their rights under the United Nations Charter to freedom of worship? Do Soviet law and the Soviet constitution guarantee such individual rights to the people of the occupied territory of Lithuania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is aware of the closure and desecration of a Catholic church in Klaipeda, Lithuania, by the Soviet authorities and of the general policy of religious repression practised by the Soviet Government. In the past the Australian Government has taken advantage of appropriate opportunities to register with the Soviet authorities the widespread concern in Australia about abuses of human rights in the USSR, and it will continue to do so. It is hoped that the expression of this kind of concern will help to persuade the Soviet Government to reconsider and to modify its policy on human rights, including the right to religious freedom. I have no factual information as to the last part of the question; I have been able to give only a general answer to Senator Lewis. If there is any further information that the Minister can provide I will see that it is given to the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Last weekend it was reported that the Government may defer the proposed construction of the new Royal Australian Air Force airfield at Derby and the Royal Australian Navy patrol base at Port Hedland in Western Australia. Is that report true?

—I did not see the report but I will give the Senate some information about the position regarding these two defence projects. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It relates to the double-handed policy on deportations. I contrast the case of a Maori New Zealander, Raymond Renata, who was deported within a matter of days, and the cases of two white New Zealanders, Brett Collins and Glen Stone, who fought a rearguard action for 12 months and who, in so doing, probably milked our legal aid system. They are still in this country notwithstanding that in the eyes of the law they are equally dangerous criminals.

—No double standards have been applied in the handling by the Minister of the cases referred to by Senator Mulvihill. The Minister ordered deportation in all three cases. The difference between the cases that have been identified by Senator Mulvihill arises from the fact that there was a difference in whether the people concerned had a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the merits of the Minister's decision. Mr Renata was a prohibited immigrant by virtue of his criminal record in New Zealand prior to his arrival in Australia. He was deported as a prohibited immigrant for that reason and, as such, does not have a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Messrs Collins and Stone were legal residents in Australia. Their deportation was ordered pursuant to section 13 of the Migration Act for convictions incurred in Australia. In one case the offence was committed in New Zealand; in the other case the offences were committed in Australia. As Mr Collins and Mr Stone were legal residents of Australia, they were entitled to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the Minister's decision.

—I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that way back during Estimates committee hearings I was told that in at least one, if not two, of the cases the New Zealand Government was diffident about taking a person back because he was born in Britain but lived in New Zealand. I think that was Glen Stone. This occurred before Christmas. I take it that the Minister 's briefing paper has nothing on that aspect.
—I am afraid that I cannot deal with those matters at this stage. I will refer them to the Minister and ask for further information.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether it is true, as reported in the Press recently, that threats and an ultimatum by the Northern Territory Government have prompted action by the Commonwealth Government and a go-ahead from the Central Land Council for construction of a gas pipeline from the Palm Valley field. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the current position in regard to this matter and whether it has been settled to the satisfaction of all concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were some articles concerning negotiations on the pipeline in the Australian last week. They were inaccurate and misleading. They have caused some confusion and some irritation. The Northern Territory Government did not issue any ultimatum to the Commonwealth as stated in the Australian. Mr Everingham, in fact, told me of the options open to the Northern Territory Government which were being examined with the aim of meeting deadlines for the pipeline construction. These deadlines arose from agreements which had been made between the Northern Territory Electricity Commission and the group developing the Palm Valley field.

ANSWER.PARA: I made it clear to Mr Everingham that only one option was acceptable and that was that we proceed with the grant of title of land under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and that we go into negotiations with the Central Land Council for the creation of an easement for the pipeline. The Northern Territory Government has accepted this view. It has asked for some understandings. We have given them. They are that the title for the land will be issued within two months and that the Central Land Council will enter into immediate negotiations on the pipeline with a view to reaching agreement on the terms of the easement by the middle of the year. Changes to the Act decided upon last year to enable title to be granted on terms acceptable to the Aboriginal people of Hermannsburg have been introduced and in fact, were passed in the Senate last week. I thank the Senate for the speedy passage that it gave this legislation. The necessary survey work for the easement has been proceeding for many months. It is nearly completed.

The articles in the Australian suggested, quite falsely, that the CLC had been unwilling to negotiate, that there was dispute among the Aboriginal people concerned, that the Hermannsburg people on this issue were pressing for the formation of a separate land council and that the traditional owners have yet to be identified. In fact, the Aboriginals concerned are ready and willing to negotiate. I have some copies of messages signed by their leaders to that effect . I will table those letters of agreement in a moment. The traditional owners have been identified. A pipeline route avoiding significant sites has been cleared by the Central Land Council. It was suggested in the Australian last week that the amendments before the Senate were some kind of response to what the Australian called 'threats by the Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, to cancel a key gas pipeline project'. Honourable senators would realise that those amendments had obviously been cleared and had been processed for some months ready for their introduction in the Senate last week.

In summary, the Aboriginal people will be granted all the land designated in Schedule 1 to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in 1976 concerning which there had been a delay. Negotiations on the gas field and on the pipeline will proceed in accordance with the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act. The go-ahead has not been given since an agreement between the CLC and the Northern Territory Government on the pipeline has yet to be concluded. I am confident that agreement of course will be reached and that another major project will be brought on stream, as have other projects which have been completed, with the proper processes of the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act being observed and put into place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of the most recent review of the Australian economy by the Bank of New South Wales which predicts fragile economic growth for Australia over the next 12 months and an inflation rate of at least 12 per cent? Is the Minister also aware that the bank has called for the re-introduction of tax indexation in order to restore some equality to the tax system? Does the Minister not agree that this report tends to contradict the rather over-optimistic outlook for the Australian economy by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development? Will the Government consider accepting the bank's sound economic advice and re-introduce tax indexation and, in so doing, provide some much needed relief for Australia's wage and salary earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw in the Press a report of the Bank of New South Wales survey. I have not had time as yet to read it and therefore I do not know its details. It is not surprising that against a world which is in a quite significant recession the bank should point to some leavening in Australia, as indeed the Prime Minister did in his state of the nation message a week or so ago. I will have a look at the details of the survey. The question of whether tax indexation should be re-introduced is a matter for the Budget. I understood that the Australian Labor Party did not have a policy in favour of tax indexation so I am surprised that the question was asked.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, although the question may overlap other portfolios. Is it a fact that the New South Wales power crisis, which has been aggravated by industrial disputation, has interfered with Australia's overseas and interstate trade? I ask whether the Minister recalls that section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:
(i) Trade and commerce with other countries, and among the States:

Does the Minister agree that this situation in New South Wales is interfering with interstate and overseas trade? It appears that the Constitution provides for the Commonwealth to make laws in this sort of emergency to deal with unions under a Federal jurisdiction to ensure that adequate maintenance is carried out at these power stations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this question comes into the bailiwick of at least three Ministers. I am aware of the New South Wales power crisis. Undoubtedly it is the most serious matter that has affected Australia as a whole for many years. Its potential for severity is extremely real. There is no doubt in the world that quite apart from its devastating effect upon those in New South Wales who will lose a significant part of their week's pay, the overall effect upon Australia in loss of production and trade is real indeed. I point out that Australia has the immense resources, both in terms of energy and minerals, to seize the opportunity to meet the demands of other countries for our trade but, unfortunately, we have not the capacity, due to artificial reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the provisions of section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution but I am totally ill-equipped to give any legal interpretation or opinion. Indeed, even if I were so equipped I would be constrained, as a Minister, from doing so. I suggest that I refer that aspect of the matter to my colleague the Attorney- General to put under study.

As for the general situation, the Commonwealth takes the very strong view that everything that can possibly be done should be done to help the people of New South Wales in their present difficulties. If there are matters we can help them with, we will do so. We are co-operating fully with regard to the Snowy Mountains. Without any request having come from New South Wales, we have imposed a voluntary restriction of electric power upon the Australian Capital Territory, and I invite all honourable senators and the people of the Australian Capital Territory to observe it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turn the floodlights off at the airport.
—I am sorry that the Labor Party finds that an objectionable practice. In fact if we--
—Why should you think that?
—Only because of the interjection.
—Senator Coates did not make any criticism of your statement.

—If that is so, I am sorry. I took it to be an adverse interjection. But if it is not, good. The fact is that the saving of electricity in the Australian Capital Territory could mean the saving of jobs for people in the State of New South Wales. Therefore, I ask for the fullest co-operation in this. I repeat that the Commonwealth is keen to do everything it can, within its capability, to assist in what is a very serious matter indeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT SURVEY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The much-vaunted and much-quoted January 1982 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey on Australia asserts:

QUESTION.PARA: Since 1978 real GDP has increased at more than twice the average rate for the OECD area as a whole.

The Prime Minister repeated that assertion last week in his electorate broadcast . Does the Prime Minister know that the most recent OECD figures show that real gross domestic product in Australia for the 2 1/2 years from December 1978 to June 1981 increased by just over 7 per cent? In the OECD as a whole in the same period the increase was 6 per cent. Seven is not more than double six; even the National Country Party should be able to work that out. Will the Prime Minister tell the Senate whether this crude attempt to falsify history and deceive the public was engineered by the Treasury or the Prime Minister, or should it be attributed to incompetence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that nobody in Australia other than Senator Walsh would accuse the OECD of a crude attempt to falsify history or to mislead the public. The fact is that the OECD published a statement in January which foreshadowed GDP growth in Australia at twice the rate of the OECD countries. I believe that was done with all the knowledge and all the independent judgment available to it. The OECD has shrewd people. They will in no way be misled in such matters, so they would not, wittingly or unwittingly, falsify history or mislead the public. They put it forward as the best skilled economic advice. One would rather rely, I think, on what they have said than on what Senator Walsh, in his diatribe, tried to draw from it. I am not aware of the other figures. I will seek them out and, if comment is necessary, I will make it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Carrick apparently believes that the OECD was making forecasts because he said that the OECD 'foreshadowed'. I ask him: Does he know that-I am quoting from the survey-' since 1978 real GDP has increased'? That is the past tense. I seek leave to table photocopies from the publication 'OECD Economic Survey of Australia, January 1982', and the 'OECD Economic Outlook' No. 30, December 1981 which prove the figures I have given.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that I would look at the figures and comment if necessary. The statement by the OECD that I referred to foreshadowed growth for Australia. I have said that whilst it had foreshadowed--
—What we want to know is whether Stone is a crook, Fraser is a crook or they are both incompetent.

—One does not wonder why one does not listen to Senator Walsh, Mr President, when there is that constant outcry. The OECD foreshadowed some 3 per cent growth in the GDP for Australia and commented that that would be roughly double the average of the OECD members. We have said, as Ministers, that that might be a modestly optimistic situation in view of the general recession, the world slowness in getting out of the recession and the inevitable impact on Australia. Nevertheless, with virtual stagnation in the OECD, the likelihood is that real growth will persist in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WEST COAST OF TASMANIA: RADIO SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. On 3 December 1980 I asked a question concerning radio services and facilities on the west coast of Tasmania. In answer, I was told by the then Minister that progress was expected and that an announcement would be made soon. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

I am advised that it is hoped that the legislation will be ready for introduction in the Budget sitting. If there is any further information I will pass it on to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a Press report in the Age of 16 March which stated that both unions and employers have now expressed opposition to the three 'anti-industrial relations Bills' proposed by Mr Viner on automatic stand-downs, enterprise unions and employment preference for unionists? In view of this, is it the Government's intention to review its confrontationist approach to industrial relations and to develop an industrial relations policy designed to promote co- operation between employers and employees? If so, what action does the Government propose to take in the present situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the Government does not propose to pursue a confrontationist policy with the trade union movement. It intends to pursue policies which will ensure that there is a reasonable balance in the Australian community between employers and employees and, indeed, between the community's interests and trade union interests. Those balances are not easy to establish and will certainly be a matter of some argument. It would be wrong to suggest that the Government is putting forward its current proposals in the spirit of confrontation.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that the basic proposals which the Government has indicated it is putting forward relate to the question of whether a man can be forced to join a trade union if he is to have a job, the question of whether an employer has to continue to pay employees even when no work is available to them because of industrial action, and the question of the basis on which trade unions should be established in Australia, whether on a craft basis, an industry basis or even , indeed, an employer basis.

Whilst I concede that there is room for honest differences in this matter I would have thought that the broad viewpoint which would be acceptable in the community would be that the fact that a man does not wish to join a union ought not be something which precludes him from obtaining employment. I would have thought that there would be general agreement that where an employer is not able to provide work for his employees, not because of his own fault but because of the fault of a trade union's action, he ought not be required to keep those people on and to pay them wages when they cannot work. I would have thought that it was common ground that, at least at the industry union level, there was considerable interest in the development of that proposal not only on this side of politics but also on the other side of politics.

As is known to the Senate-indeed, it has been the subject of some discussion- there have been consultations between the Government and the major interested parties, namely, employers and the trade unions, with respect to the proposals that Mr Viner, on behalf of the Government, has indicated he is bringing forward . Those consultaions have extended over some time and the Government is considering the views which have been put forward during those consultations in arriving at the final shape of the proposal which is to be put before the Parliament for its consideration and, I trust, approval. There has been debate in the Senate about what has gone to the National Labour Consultative Council. I do not think that it will advance the matter. I know the honourable senators opposite do not want me to debate the matter in Question Time. I can only say in response to the question which has been asked by Senator Siddons that there have useful consultations with both trade unions and employers. Those consultations have certainly had an influence on the shape of what is to be brought before this Parliament and what is being done is not being done in a spirit of confrontation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to the confusion which has arisen because holders of health care cards have received letters outlining income limits for their continuing eligibility? Are the limits mentioned in the advice, for which a health care card will be renewed, set at 125 per cent of the initial eligibility level and above? Has any action been taken to alter the advice to card holders to remove the current confusion?

—I am not aware of any confusion in that area. I am aware of some difficulties which have arisen with respect to the renewal of cards at the expiration of the six months entitlement. Legislation will, in fact, be coming before the chamber shortly to remove that potential difficulty. I will examine the material which has been sent out to health care card holders and see whether there is a problem as outlined by the honourable senator in his question.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Education to the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission entitled Program Guidelines 1982 which shows that $100,000 will go towards education of girls under the Special Projects Program in the context of equalising educational opportunities. I ask the Minister: Has the Commission's recently established Working Party on the Education of Girls identified any areas where inequality exists apart from the discriminatory attitudes of either some teachers or some parents? If so, what are those areas? How did they come about?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Did the Civil Works Program for 1980- 81, Budget Paper No. 5, contain an estimate of $12m for proposed rehabilitation of the Finniss River area associated with Rum Jungle? If so, can the Minister advise how much of this money has been spent by the Northern Territory Government, which undertook to do the work on behalf of the Commonwealth Government? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT: GOVERNMENT FUNDING

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is it true that the Federal Government has slashed finance for industrial research and development? Is it also true that more than 120 Australian companies will not now receive the funds they expected this year? Were these funds committed in this year's Budget? What effect will this move have on current and future research projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the discussions leading up to the settling of the Additional Estimates some figures were arranged with regard to industrial research and development grants. I did see a Press report on this matter and I have asked for a report as to its accuracy or otherwise. I have not the detailed information with me. Some figures have been given with regard to forward commitments. Some other figures were discussed with regard to this year's Budget . I think it would be better if I were to seek the specific information arising from that Press report and advise the honourable senator a little later about the matter.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the gift that this Government has made to the highly profitable banking sector through the housing finance measures announced last Thursday. Is the Treasurer aware that the 1981 profits of the five largest private banks total $560m? Is it a fact that the banks will be given a further profit boost of the order of $75m as a result of a lift in interest rate charges on existing home loans and at least another $50m as a result of the increased interest rates payable on statutory reserve deposits? Does the Treasurer acknowledge that the only net beneficiaries of the new housing finance measures are the banks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — To answer the last part of the question first, I think the Treasurer would not acknowledge that the only beneficiaries of the housing package announced last week would be the banks, for the very simple reason that in the package there are some additional measures that directly relate to individuals through the tax rebate system. Other proposals will be of assistance to individuals in their quest for a home. As far as citing figures on the profitability of banks is concerned, I think we would always need to look at the capital employed before looking at profit. Certainly in some areas of the lending capacity of the banking sector, there has now been an increase in interest rates. But everyone who looks at the banking sector or the other part of the financial sector would realise that in order to be able to lend money such banking and other institutions must be able to borrow money. In the whole process of what has been arranged with the banks a further $400m will be released to assist those people who are seeking loans for their home purchase. That in itself should make it possible for thousands of people to receive loans in a way in which they would not have been able to do had we not had the whole package which was put before the Parliament last week. I could not agree-I am sure the Treasurer would not agree-that the only beneficiaries are the banks. In fact, I think the Treasurer has already acknowledged the great co-operation which came from the banks in assisting us in putting together the package which we believe will be of benefit to many thousands of Australians.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ISOLATED PATIENTS TRAVEL AND ACCOMMODATION ASSISTANCE SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Health to the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme, IPTAAS, which reimburses patients who have been referred to specialists for expenses incurred in travelling for treatment more than 200 kilometres away. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.PARA: I may have more information for the honourable senator. Knowing that Senator Kilgariff wanted some particular answers, we have tried to get some information from the Minister for Health. We will take up the matters he has raised. I emphasise once again that under the new cost sharing agreements the States and the Territory do have an increased flexibility. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: Is he aware that the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust is attempting to arrange a tour to the United States and Canada this year of the Australian Aboriginal Theatre's production of The Cake Man? Is the Minister also aware that this important Aboriginal play has been invited to represent Australia at the World Festival of Theatre in Denver, Colorado, in July and that further performance dates have been secured in New York, San Francisco, Vancouver, Toronto, Alberta and Los Angeles? —I will answer this question in two parts. I can state what I have done as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Foreman proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The worsening unemployment situation in Australia and, in particular, the continuation of an unacceptably high unemployment rate amongst teenagers, under the restrictive economic policies of the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a national crisis : This country's highest level of unemployment on record and this Government's restrictive economic policies which have contributed to this grave situation. Despite all the futile attempts by the Fraser Government to hide the true extent of unemployment in this country, such as getting rid of the politically embarrassing Commonwealth Employment Service figures, one thing it cannot run away from this time is the fact that official Australian Bureau of Statistics figures now show that 482,600 people are out of work in this country. In other words, 7 per cent of the work force, or one in every 14 people, is looking for work. Of course the official figure does not include the estimated 400,000 people who comprise the hidden unemployed. As the shadow Minister for employment , Mr Bob Hawke, has rightly claimed, if they were included the real unemployment figure would be somewhere around 12 per cent. The February jobless total represents an increase of 43,000 over the January figure and a massive increase of over 58,000 or 14 per cent since February of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this Government came to power unemployment has increased by 41 per cent and the average duration of unemployment has risen from 13 weeks in 1975 to 30 weeks in 1981. This recent upsurge in unemployment is almost entirely due to the penny-pinching, restrictive monetary policies of the Fraser Government and, in particular, the 1981-82 Howard Budget which was designed deliberately to slow down the economy. Employment growth figures confirm that statement. Over the last 18 months the growth in employment has slowed down considerably from 3 1/2 per cent in the September quarter of 1980 to less than 1.6 per cent in the year to January. The prospect of this growth rate falling even further in the months ahead is real indeed.There is no hope at all of employment growth being large enough to soak up any likely future growth in the labour force.

In a moment, I suppose, we will hear claims by Government senators that employment growth has been strong over the last few years, as indeed it has. But over the last 18 months the growth rate has slowed down alarmingly. That is what this debate is all about. We are talking about, on the most recent indications, the future of half a million Australians who are officially listed as unemployed , as well as the other 400,000 I mentioned before who do not show up in the official figures. There is no point in Government senators attempting to deny the fact that unemployment has reached a crisis point in this country. They know that the indicators are bad and that there is absolutely nothing they can produce to show that things will become better.

One of the most distressing aspects of the unemployment crisis is the impact it is having on the older age group. Many people have been displaced through technological change. Once they are retrenched, they have very little hope of being re-employed. This group also constitutes a large proportion of the hidden unemployed, as many people are reluctant to admit to being without a job. Of course, this disadvantaged section of the community has been ignored by this Government. The current economic policies of the Fraser Government have given them absolutely no hope at all of regaining their self-esteem. Moreover, the Government continually refuses to face up to the problem being inflicted upon middle-aged and older workers by changes in technology.

I now turn to the other crisis area. Certainly it has the most dangerous ramifications for the future of Australia. I refer to the very serious and potentially explosive problem of youth unemployment. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that 136,000 teenagers are looking for full time work in Australia. This represents an increase of 7 per cent over February last year and an increase of more than 14 per cent over the life of the Fraser Government. The current teenage unemployment rate is almost four times higher than the adult unemployment rate. In other words, one in every five teenagers is out of work. If Government senators think they can stand in this chamber and say that there is nothing to worry about and everything will be all right, they had better think again. I admit that teenage unemployment fell slightly between January and February but this was largely due to teenagers going back to school or opting out of the work force.

The most recent employment growth figures show that teenage employment actually fell by 23,200 in the year to January. In addition, there has been a fall in the teenage participation rate of about one per cent which means, in effect, that the situation is so bad that many teenagers have just given up any hope of ever finding a job. This fall in the participation rate, coupled with a fall of about 10,000 in the population in the 15 to 19 year age group are the only reasons that the fall in teenage job levels has not been translated into an increase in the official teenage unemployment rate. If these trends continue Australia will be faced with the same sort of social upheaval as Great Britain, with riots in the streets and a spiralling crime rate. In Britain increasing numbers of unemployed teenagers have joined extremist organisations and have resorted to looting and gang warfare simply because they have nothing better to do. I am sure that none of us wants to see this happen in Australia but this is what could happen if nothing is done soon to stop the job rot.

Another frightening aspect of youth unemployment concerns a finding by Professor Russell Mears, Professor of Psychiatry at Sydney University. He has claimed that unemployment could be a significant cause behind a doubling in the suicide rate among the 15 to 19-year-olds over the last five years. In addition, it has been revealed that unemployed youths have far more health problems than employed youths. The majority of these problems, according to Dr Harris of the Department of Community Medicine at the Flinders University of South Australia, are stress-related illnesses. He has claimed that a study conducted in Ballarat, Victoria, had shown that unemployed people are 12 times more likely to attempt suicide than employed people.

Another alarming trend is the increasing incidence of prostitution amongst young people, both male and female. Unemployment has forced many young people on to the streets of Kings Cross in Sydney, St Kilda in Melbourne and Hindley Street in Adelaide just so that they can get enough money to pay the rent and, in some cases, to pay for their drinking and drug habits. The Channel 9 program 60 Minutes recently showed how widespread the problem of teenage drinking has become and how unemployment is often the cause of this tragedy. In many cases, gangs of unemployed youths have bashed and robbed innocent people just to get money for their drinking habits. Even in Adelaide people are now afraid to walk the streets at night for fear of being mugged, raped or even murdered. Of course , honourable senators opposite would rather pretend that all this does not happen and that unemployment is not responsible. But it is a fact that teenage prostitution and teenage alcoholism have become rampant through the ineptness of the Fraser Government. We are being plunged into a Clockwork Orange society faster than we think.

Shortly we will probably hear Government senators saying that youth unemployment is not confined to Australia. This is certainly true. Recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures show that Australia has one of the highest youth unemployment rates of all OECD countries. Despite this, since 1975 expenditure on manpower programs has decreased in real terms by 44 per cent. I think this is fairly indicative of the degree of this Government's inaction and lack of concern for the problem of youth unemployment. Schemes such as the Community Youth Support Scheme and the Education Program for Unemployed Youth are very useful, of course, and play a most important role. But the fact of the matter is that they do not provide jobs. Despite all the emotive claims about dole bludgers a clear majority of young unemployed Australians want to work; it should be every government's role to ensure that they are given the opportunity.

The severe deterioration of employment opportunities for young people over the last year is almost entirely due to this Government's restrictive economic policies. Already the same sort of monetary policies in Britain have caused unemployment in that country to reach 12 per cent. The 1981-82 Howard Budget was deliberately aimed at slowing down the rate of growth in the Australian economy and, therefore, indirectly at slowing down the rate of growth in employment. Because of this thousands of young Australians have been denied jobs. The outlook is certainly not very promising. Recent figures on retail sales, which Government senators have claimed in the past are a very good economic indicator, show that spending is being curtailed. Figures released on 3 March by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that in January retail sales increased by only 0.2 per cent over December compared with an increase of 0.7 per cent for the same period a year earlier. In other words, retail sales are now increasing at only a third of the rate in 1981. If this trend continues retail sales in real terms will fall by around 6 per cent in 1982.

This has very serious implications for our manufacturing industries and hence employment opportunities generally. Even the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd has recently started massive retrenchments. The Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia is predicting that 1982 will be a very difficult year for metal and engineering industries. According to the most recent review of the Australian economy by the Bank of New South Wales, Australia is facing fragile economic growth over the next 12 months. Even in the mining industry employers are now claiming that employment has reached its peak.

Where will the growth in the employment come from? It is not good enough for Ministers of the Government of this country to shake their heads and blame the depressed international economic climate for our problems. It is not good enough for Government senators to blame everything on the Whitlam Labor Government of something like seven or eight years ago; the people stopped listening to that nonsense a long time ago. The young unemployed people of this country want more than just words from the Fraser Government. They want jobs, something that they cannot get from the Government's present array of training schemes or the Government's present economic policies, something the so-called 'beat inflation first' strategy will never give them. The level of unemployment over the next decade will, of course, largely be determined by the economic growth rate. An annual growth rate of around 5 per cent will be needed just to absorb expansions in the labour force and increases in productivity. In other words, a growth rate of at least 6 per cent is required if we are to achieve some fall in the level of unemployment. Under the Fraser Government we now have a growth rate of only about 2 per cent. Some sort of stimulus to the economy is urgently needed before irreparable damage is done. As the editorial in the Australian of 15 January pointed out:

. . . the political and social consequences of widespread and lasting unemployment can be horrendous. Without millions of frustrated German unemployed it is highly unlikely that Hitler would ever have been able to take power. It is at least arguable that, without Northern Ireland's high proportion of jobless, the province's endemic sectarianism would not have been accompanied by the present terrifying blood-letting.
The same editorial went on to say:

If unemployment continues for much longer at its present level, it will not only blight the lives of those who are unemployed. It will radically change the nature of our society for the worse. Its elimination must be among the most important of our national goals.

I would suggest to the Government that it accept this advice and devote all its energies towards solving the unemployment crisis in this country instead of engaging in union bashing and introducing such draconian legislation as the Social Services Amendment Bill and the new industrial relations legislation. Perhaps if the Government had not abandoned wage indexation and tax indexation and forced up indirect taxes, interest rates and so on, we would not have had so many wage demands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! the honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to enter this discussion on the alleged worsening unemployment situation in Australia which has a particular reference to young people and the restrictive economic policies of the Fraser Government. Any significant measure of unemployment is unacceptable. I do not believe there is any argument about that at all. The argument needs to be directed to the areas that have caused the unemployment situation and how best they can be solved. If we are to serve the purpose of the unemployed-particularly the young unemployed-in this country we had better concern ourselves not so much with constant, often irrelevant and uninformed statistics, but rather with how best we can isolate the causes of unemployment and how best, as a total community, we can contribute to solving those problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I expand a little on that issue I must say that there were one or two matters that Senator Foreman mentioned in his very responsible address with which I cannot totally agree. He said that during the term of the Fraser Government the unemployment rate has gone up by 41 per cent. As I said, I do not propose this afternoon to talk specifically in terms of statistics, but it is my belief that over the five-year or six-year period of this Government the unemployment rate has increased by more like 20 per cent than 40 per cent. If we follow that through to the circumstances that existed during the three years of the socialist regime, we will see that the unemployment rate increased-as I recall it-by something like 150 per cent. Senator Foreman mentions that we should be talking about the last 18 months. I am quite happy to talk about the last 18 months but I see no necessity so to do. We are dealing with the overall question of unemployment in our society during the terms of all governments, I would assume, not only the Fraser Government.

Senator Foreman also mentioned the problems associated with technological change. I hope to expand in some measure on that area because I believe it is of very great importance. The challenges that confront Australians, particularly young Australians, as a result of technological change are among the most significant that we as a government and as a people have to overcome. Senator Foreman also mentioned that in February the unemployment situation concerning young people was a little worse than usual. That is so, although somewhat ironically it is not as bad as it was five years ago. There is no doubt that in February it is normal for the unemployment position, particularly concerning young people, to be a significant problem because so many young people are moving into a totally new world for the first time. They are being confronted with challenges that do not seem to exist in the course of one's school life. Certainly, these challenges bear enormous proportions when one moves into the world outside. So on those grounds it is normal that, in terms of employment, February is a month of enormous readjustment. It is a very difficult month, one in which we normally find greater numbers unemployed than at other periods. It is evident more than ever in February that it is necessary for a whole range of skills to be acquired if certain forms of employment are to be achieved. So one finds at around that time of the year a great number of young people in this country looking at the sort of transitional circumstance in which they find themselves.

I believe that when we are discussing a matter such as the unemployment situation-let us face it, we have discussed it at intermittent times over the past three to five years and I am sure that we discussed it during the socialist regime-we should analyse the possible solutions to a problem that is around us and around the rest of the developed world. In most of the developed world the problem is far more significant and tragic than it is in Australia today. Very often, when we look at the history of events we are able to isolate in some measure the causes of those events. If we can isolate the causes of the events then we have some real possibility of establishing a number of solutions. It occurs to me that during the period from 1946 to 1973 there was in this country, by standards anywhere in the world and by standards of history at any particular time, a very low rate of unemployment. In 1972 the unemployment level, as I recall, was something like 2.2 per cent of the work force.

In the period from 1973 to 1976 there was an enormous escalation of wages- incidentally, the same threat confronts Australia today-and we saw a significant transfer of Australian resources from the private to the public sector. In that period-again, if I recall the statisics accurately-the number of unemployed in this country increased by 2 1/2 times. From 1976 to the present time, 1982, the unemployment figure has varied marginally up and marginally down. But unfortunately and regrettably it has varied up basically from about 5 per cent of the work force to about 6 per cent in round figures. What has happened is that we have steadied the rate of increase of unemployment very significantly. Having said that, I will not go further and say that that is in any sense sufficient. Let it be said that it is not much more than a trend-a step in the right direction-and it should give us confidence and determination to follow out that tendency.

What then can we say of the causes of the unemployment problem that confronts this country along with most other developed countries-indeed, all other developed countries? I would have no hesitation in saying that the basic cause relates to wage explosion and the accompanying inflation. I know that these are not new words; they have been said hundreds of times. Why should they not be said hundreds of times when they are correct? The wage explosion and the accompanying inflation rate are destroying confidence and creating the very unemployment that this important discussion this afternoon is about.

The coalition has tried, I believe, quite desperately to restrain wage rate increases. It has tried by the only two methods, I suppose, that are open to it. There is the example in its own area. It has been participating in a proper and vigorous representation in the courts which decide wage levels, suggesting that until wages in this country are in some way related to the capacity of the economy to pay, we will, of course, be confronted continually by an economic situation which has in its very being the essence of unemployment. The unions regrettably-I say 'regrettably' with a great deal of consideration-have demanded maximum wage levels to the extent, I believe, of irresponsibility. I believe that their demands have made the circumstances of young Australians infinitely worse. Their opportunities of employment cannot be improved by having relatively unskilled young people seeking employment at a wage rate that no one on earth could comply with and remain solvent.

The real solution, as many people have said and will continue to say, lies in the establishment of a buoyant economy, an economy which seeks to provide employment for all the people available with all their skills and for the simple reason of buoyancy itself, because out of that is bred confidence and a determination to produce and to provide the goods and services that the varying markets within and without this country demand. In relation to the allegedly restrictive economic policies of the Fraser Government, let me say that the growth rate of this country even today is estimated at something in the vicinity of 3 per cent, when the growth rate of the European Community is marginally more than one per cent. So even today, under all sorts of international restrictions and disincentives, the growth rate in Australia is nearly 200 per cent greater than it is, for instance, in the developed countries of Western Europe.

The Government has consistently followed a course of developing energy exploration and research in this country with the establishment of vast infrastructure and incentive to industry across a very wide range. Indeed, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development very recently included Australia amongst the most efficient and the most promising economies in the developed world. It would also have said that it was not so promising or literally as efficient as it was perhaps a year or two ago. Which economy on earth is in other than that situation?

That there is a steadying in our galloping unemployment rate is borne out by the February figures. I shall not continue statistically for more than a moment or two, but it is interesting to note that even in February 1982 the unemployment level was 7 per cent. In 1981 it was 6.3 per cent; in 1980 it was 6 .7 per cent; in 1979 it was 6.9 per cent; and in 1978-five years ago-it was 7.3 per cent. So, there has been a variant of one percentage point or less over that period. We must in fairness compare those percentages with the unemployment figures in the United States 8.5 per cent, in the United Kingdom of 11.7 per cent and in the countries of the European Community of 10 per cent to 11 per cent. I mention those figures not because they are of themselves extraordinarily satisfactory in any field at all-they are far from satisfactory-but because they indicate that in the context of the Western, developed world the Australian situation is significantly better than that of its fellow economies around the world. In February teenage employment in Australia showed a fall of 9,700. The 12 months to January 1982 saw an increase in employment of 102,000 or 1.6 per cent. Over the two years to January 1982 the increase in employment was, very significantly, 242,000 or 4 per cent.

I could not participate in this discussion without coming to the second cause of the unemployment situation, which cause surely relates to the problems of unions and management in coping with the advent of highly sophisticated technology in an industrial and commercial world where the cost of labour has been so great that that advent has accelerated to a point beyond the capacity of the community and the educational systems to cope. One of the great challenges which has been accepted by this Government significantly across a very wide range has been to adopt its educational system so that the people who come out of the end of the educational pipeline are equipped with the skills, the capacities and determination that Australian commerce and industry are seeking and urgently need.

In this field the Government has placed significant emphasis. It has continually increased the area of expenditure and opportunity in technical and further education. It has instigated the important school to work transition program. As from 27 January it reinstigated the Community Youth Support Scheme, after having carried out an in-depth investigation of it in co-operation with the community, and established new guidelines which will tend to place greater emphasis than ever on its capacity to produce from its ranks young people who are able to be gainfully employed in the industry and commerce areas of our community. The Government has greatly increased the opportunities for apprenticeship. Indeed, apprenticeship in Australia today is at the highest level of its history. In 1981-82, 230,000 Australians, including over 200,000 young Australians, will be assisted by manpower training programs.

Finally, I come back to a significant area which is a cause for concern and which has to be overcome if unemployment is to be confronted and defeated. I am surprised and disappointed that Senator Foreman did not responsibly direct his remarks to this area. It is my complete and absolute view that the greatest contributor to unemployment in this country has been the level of industrial unrest. A measure of uncertainty is developing not only within this country but also without it. A level of uncertainty exists in Australia as a supplier. A measure of doubt is slowly moving into other countries about this country's being a great producer and a great supplier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that it was totally predictable that we would see an effort by the Government to minimise the February unemployment figures. But I believe also that that quite misses the point. The trend in the statistics is unmistakable. We can look at very important aspects of unemployment, such as its average duration, and find that now, in the 15 to 19 year old age group, the average period of unemployment is 25.7 weeks-very close to six months-and the mean is 14.9 weeks. In the 20 to 24 year old age group, many of whom have been unemployed since leaving school, the average period of unemployment is 30.4 weeks. Youth unemployment has risen from June 1975 what it was 32 per cent of the total unemployed to December 1981 when it was 39 per cent of the total unemployed. Since 1975 the 15 to 24 year age group has accounted for over 50 per cent of the total number of people unemployed in Australia. These trends, I insist again, are unmistakably in a direction which indicates that our matter of public importance is perfectly legitimate.

SPEECH.PARA: For the whole of the wage indexation period to which Senator Scott referred, the vast majority of workers and their unions claimed only cost of living increases and in most cases received less. Despite this restraint, unemployment grew, inflation grew, standards of living declined and the security of the average worker also declined and, with it there was inevitable industrial unrest . I remind honourable senators that it was the Fraser Government which opposed and finally killed wage indexation.

Currently, only 43 per cent of our school leavers are being absorbed, each year , into the work force. This is happening in the face of the fact that Australia is expecting a gigantic 8.4 per cent increase in its work force participation rates over the next five years. Youth unemployment has always been higher than the average. In 1970, when the general level of unemployment was 1.4 per cent, youth unemployment was 3.2 per cent. In February 1982 when the general level was 7 per cent youth unemployment was 20.1 per cent. These figures show the number of unemployed as a percentage of the labour force in the 15 to 19 year age group . I remind honourable senators too, that we no longer receive any estimates of job vacancies from the Bureau of Statistics.

Young women have always been at a greater disadvantage. At present, their unemployment rate is 23.4 per cent as against 17.7 per cent for young men in the same age group. Opportunities for females at every age are circumscribed by the increasingly vicious dual labour market in Australia which has always restricted the range of occupations available to women. When the Australian Statistician takes out his quarterly figures in relation to average award earnings he looks at 2,500 common awards for men and about only 500 for women. The incomes of women reflect this restriction which is generally towards the lower earning end of the scale. Only 12 per cent of full time employed males earned less than $150 a week in August 1980; 27 per cent of full time employed women earned less than $150 per week at the same time. Only 2.6 per cent of the female labour force has trade qualifications as against over 20 per cent of men in the work force.

A third labour market is developing as the structure of the work force changes. One section is for the mature woman, who, in many cases, has no formal skills but who has acquired a great many skills in the course of running a household and bringing up a family. There is another, much smaller, labour market for junior girls. The traditional junior jobs in shops and factories and banks and offices, which absorbed most female school leavers, have changed drastically, diminished dramatically or disappeared altogether. The majority of jobs available for the girl leaving school at age 15, or even for the more fortunate girl who stayed at school for a little longer, are unlikely to lead to satisfying careers. Some domestic-type work, some assembly-line work, some clerical work and some jobs in the retail trade are available. In many cases, this type of employment has become casualised, at worse, or has become part time , which is marginally better. In August 1980, 14 per cent of part time workers were aged 15 to 19 years and were concentrated in the service, clerical and sales occupational groups.

The average part time hours worked over all age groups are about 16 hours per week. But many of the part time workers in the junior age group are still at school. Many of them work very few hours-the average, in fact, is seven hours per week. These mini-jobs can be defended, I suppose, in terms of much needed income and the acquisition of work experience. But, in view of the nature of the jobs-packers, wrappers, waitresses, short-order cooks, cleaners, counterhands and labourers-one wonders just what will be learnt about job satisfaction except , perhaps, that it is a harsh world and that only the fittest survive. In this climate of contracting full time job opportunities for teenagers, the responses of the Government have been inept, wasteful, misguided and tardy.

The important questions have barely been addressed. If teenage employment is declining, should secondary education be more job-oriented or less? How should the total curriculum respond to the needs of students who would previously have entered the work force without completing Year 10? Is there a case for teaching vocational skills for living and leisure rather than vocational skills for work? If so, who should do the teaching-schools or colleges of technical and further education? Are schools prepared to accept the responsibility to make a genuine effort to broaden the career aspirations of girls and equip them with appropriate skills in order to prevent them from becoming increasingly locked out of the labour market? Furthermore, what really is the point of increasing the job-seeking skills of the young which is a crude and cruel carrot and stick approach, I suggest, when jobs themselves are more and more difficult to get.

There is certainly a case for increasing the confidence of young women who tend to be much less visible than their unemployed brothers. But no special schemes have yet been devised for young unemployed women. To the extent that it might be argued that there should be no bias, it is obvious that if the present schemes are not of much use for boys, for girls they are worse than useless. The net increase in training opportunities in all schemes has been insignificant in the last year. The 1981-82 Budget anticipated that the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training would be available to an additional 3,000 apprentices, that there would be 8,000 additional enrolments in pre- apprenticeship schemes and pre-vocational courses and that 8,600 new Special Youth Employment Training Program places would be made available-something like 20,000 positions in all, many of which, I remind honourable senators, would relate to short term employment. This is in the face of 140,000-odd unemployed young people. Scarce skills, where they have been identified in what I suggest is a totally inadequate approach to labour force planning in this country, are in trade areas related to the resources boom and are mostly reserved for males.

Perhaps the most cynical exercise in the entire Budget last year was the large increase in subsidies to employers for various training programs. In 1981-82, these amounted to about $140m or 70 per cent of the training and youth opportunities program. The biggest increase has been in SYETP under which employers receive subsidies for 17 or 34-week periods to provide young people with work experience. This Program has been strongly criticised by many groups as being tokenistic, not leading to any real jobs, recycling unemployment and being abused by employers as a source of cheap labour for menial and unskilled jobs.

The National Employment and Training Scheme was instituted initially as a means of assisting women particularly or people who had been out of the work force for any time to acquire skills which would be marketable. It has been allowed to run down over the last years to a point where it is practically useless. I believe that it could certainly be resuscitated especially to assist young women who are discouraged by their past failures and their expectations for the immediate future. Despite the fact that females outnumber males in the unemployed 15 to 19 -year age group, fewer use the CYSS offices on a regular basis, fewer enrol with the Commonwealth Employment Service, some marry very young or have babies to give meaning to their existence, while many just stay at home. A study made of the characteristics of unemployed youth was published in the Journal of Industrial Relations in September 1978. Referring to the girls, the study states :
