Their previous lack of success, plus the reduced opportunity to look for work, further lowered their confidence and they became caught in a vicious circle, they had to do housework because they were unemployed and they were unemployed because they had to do housework.

This country is in urgent need of a comprehensive youth policy with special attention to projects for young women. I have already addressed many of the questions which have yet to be asked, let alone answered. If the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is genuine in deploring the fact that higher education participation rates are falling, what does he intend to do to make the education system relevant to the youth of the 1980s? Will this society re-order its priorities to make sufficient funds available so that so-called transition programs, or their equivalent, will begin to cater for the vast numbers of young people who are becoming acutely aware of their lack of skills?

Perhaps the Government could start by evaluating the schemes which have already been funded to quite an extensive point-about $500,000 has been spent over the last four years in various training schemes-and introduce the concept of accountability of those employers who have already been so heavily subsidised by the Government to such little effect. To my knowledge no employers have been called anything like the equivalent of dole bludgers, nor have employers been persecuted for abusing the schemes. A publication by the Australian Council of Social Service entitled: 'Work, . . . or the want of it' states:
. . . they rob the taxpayer by taking the subsidised young person, using him, teaching him nothing, then dumping him to hire another subsidised trainee.

The failures and injustices of SYETP are well known within the bureaucracy, but the Government chooses to ignore them. Nevertheless its inadequacies are used as fresh weapons by bureaucrats to discredit the suggestions of job creation. While there are no job prospects for the vast majority of young people, many of whom are also homeless and without hope, this Government stands condemned of criminal neglect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone in Australia would be gravely concerned at the unemployment level in this country. Honourable senators in this place are equally concerned that something needs to be done about it. Nevertheless, the trend is an international one. Australia's record is comparatively good when compared with those other countries. The figures for the September quarter last year are: The United States, 7.1 per cent unemployed; France, 7.8 per cent; the United Kingdom, 11.4 per cent; Italy 8.2 per cent and Canada, 7.4 per cent; and Australia's unemployment rate was 5.7 per cent. The only two countries with a level of unemployment lower than that of Australia were Japan with 2.2 per cent and West Germany with 4.8 per cent. Since then the unemployment situation has become slightly worse. We are all concerned about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested to observe the comments that have been made by Senator Foreman. I point out that steps can be taken to alleviate the unemployment position. I cite an example in South Australia where there is a huge deposit of minerals at the Olympic Dam. The South Australian Government, the Tonkin Government, has been endeavouring to pass an indenture Bill which-once it passed the two Houses- would provide job opportunities for many thousands of people in South Australia directly and indirectly as a result of the exploitation of that world-scale mineral deposit. I find it quite strange that the Labor Party Opposition in South Australia has chosen to frustrate the passage of that indenture Bill. Having regard to the significance that Senator Foreman and the Opposition have placed upon the need for development and the provision of jobs in Australia, I hope that that attitude will be reflected very soon in the South Australian Parliament and that that indenture Bill will have a speedy passage through those two Houses. Its passage will mean that the companies concerned will then be able to authorise an expenditure of $100m to continue their exploration and feasibility studies for that project.

I sometimes wonder whether we should analyse the unemployment figures. In Australia today something like 36,700 jobs are available. Traditionally one has to agree that of those included among the unemployed many are unemployable. A few years ago I was doing some work on this matter. It was recognised at that time that 20 per cent were unemployable. This included those people who cannot hold a job for longer than a week or so. Another statistic that comes to my mind -this is according to the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs at the time I last had a look at this figure-is that a third of the people who are recorded as unemployed had left their jobs voluntarily for one reason or another. They may have had an aversion to their foreman or the person they worked against, their boss; they may not have got on too well with them. If we add those figures up-it is pretty difficult to be accurate with respect to those percentages-that reduces the unemployment figure considerably.

Let us look at another aspect; that is, how many of the remaining unemployed would be willing to take the 36,700 available jobs? I recall a year or two ago when my son was without work. He was waiting to enter the police force. For six weeks it looked as though he might be unemployed, but he regarded it as his responsibility to look for a job. He went to the unemployment office and the first question asked of him was: 'Do you want unemployment benefit?' He said: ' No, I want a labouring job. I am prepared to take anything that is available.' He walked out of that office with disgust because the first thing offered him was a carrot of unemployment benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they get him a labouring job?

—He got a job on the end of a shovel mixing concrete to toughen himself up. It did him a lot of good. It expanded and broadened his experience. It might not hurt some of us to follow his example. In due course he was able to sustain himself and provide for his needs during that period. Eventually he went into the police force. I just wonder how many people are in that category. They may be waiting to go into a job of their first choice but in the meantime a job may be available that would enable them to survive. I think that matter of responsibility ought to be examined as well. There may be people in that category.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall, I think it was about 18 months ago, talking to an employer, a mechanic, who had a car servicing business in the Adelaide Hills. He told me that he employed a mechanic who proved to be so good that the employer wanted to retain his services by providing him with an increase in wages after he had been with him for one month. However, two months later-three months in all was the period of the mechanic's employment-the employee came up to the boss and said: ' I have to resign'. The employer said: 'Why? Your work is good. I was going to offer you a greater interest in the work that you are doing. This would be reflected in further wage increases for you'. The employee said: 'I am living with three or four other people in a house. It is my turn to go on unemployment benefits'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true. It is rubbish.
—That is not rubbish; it is true.
—It is rubbish to generalise.

—I am asking whether we should not have a closer look at the reasons for people leaving jobs and whether we should not increase our efficiency in respect of follow-up procedures that may be necessary. In saying that I am painting some sort of picture of the difficulties that we are faced with in Australia today. I look at the situation in New South Wales where even Mr Wran is concerned-quite properly so. As I suggested in Question Time today, the New South Wales situation is interfering with interstate and international trade. Mr Wran said that some power workers had declared war on their work mates in New South Wales and also the community. He said that the Government would not bow to their blackmail and would not be held to ransom. He said that the Government condemned the arrogant attempt by power workers to gain their industrial ends by using their mailed fist. Mr Wran also made a comment about the way in which the workers in these unions were carrying on after having obtained a wage rise of, I think, $35 a week. They then decided to continue their efforts and to subject their fellow workers to even greater trouble. Mr Wran referred also to railway disputes when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that leaders of the ARU were hell bent on having a strike whatever happened.

I think these things have to be examined in the light of responsibility in a sincere attempt to overcome our problems. I remember a very eminent Minister for Labour once saying that one man's wage rise cost another man his job. I thought that Clyde Cameron's words were very true. That is another aspect that we have to look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Frank Crean.

—Thank you, Senator Tate. I believe that if more people in the Labor Party agreed with that proposition and brought some sort of sense to prevail in the powerful minority in the trade union movement that would help significantly in overcoming our problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the matter of Olympic Dam in South Australia. To bring that mine up to the full mining stage, it is estimated, will cost the companies concerned about $1 billion to $1.5 billion. So far 32 drilling holes have been completed and a $15m exploration shaft has been sunk to a depth of 260 metres. The projected employment, as at last year, is at least 250 jobs directly associated with that exploration project. I think we have to recognise that all State governments have responsibility to examine all their policies. I think the Federal Government ought to have another look at the proposition I put some time ago. I believe this has a lot of support among my colleagues and others in the community. My suggestion was to provide finance that will enable the States and, of course, the Commonwealth to embark upon capital works programs that are of an essential character and which will contribute to national and State development.

Last week I believe the Premier of South Australia called for a conference of State Premiers and the Commonwealth to examine the situation that is developing in this country. I think that governments ought to be able to arrange finance at an appropriate interest rate which would not contribute to inflation. Money could be provided for water storage facilities and road works-whether it be the reconstruction of highways such as the Hume Highway or the construction of new roads which are necessary for industrial development in mining areas-and for the development of the tourist industry. I think we also ought to be able to look at the financing of railways that will contribute to mining development as well as other industrial developments such as coal handling facilities, wharves, bridges and power stations. Obviously, something has gone wrong in New South Wales because the State Government ought to have been able to provide more power generation facilities. Perhaps there is some way in which the Commonwealth can assist to repair the damage that has obviously been done over the years. Those are the things I would like to see the Federal Government consider. I would like to see adequate finance provided to enable the States and the Commonwealth to embark upon projects, such as those I have mentioned, which are of a national asset building character, which will provide jobs and which, I hope, will alleviate the unemployment problem in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is indebted to Senator Dominic Foreman for raising as a matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The worsening unemployment situation in Australia and, in particular, the continuation of an unacceptably high unemployment rate amongst teenagers, under the restricted economic policies of the Fraser Government.

There is no doubt that we are faced with social devastation against which the economic degradation of the environment, which is so often inveighed against, pales into insignificance. We are in a situation where 486,000 fellow Australians are officially tallied as seeking employment and unable to find it- 486,000 Australians. If the population of Tasmania, man, woman and child, were subject to the same social devastation, the same deprivations, the same lack of finance to obtain the necessities of life, decent food and access to proper health and education facilities-all those things that are suffered by the unemployed at the moment-this chamber would be in an uproar. There would be talk of secession from the federation; there would be a feeling that the federation might be on the verge of collapse. The unemployed are geographically and socially dispersed throughout the nation and this is an occasion for yet another debate in the Senate, but a ho hum feeling seems to prevail.

In fact we are faced with what I have termed social devastation. The individual suffering is difficult to present to this chamber. I think a socially structured problem is being created, and, as Senator Foreman so eloquently outlined, it should be the real concern of this chamber and indeed of this Parliament. I believe that the allegiance of many Australians to our political and economic social system is being weakened because that system is not delivering the sort of well-being or the standard of living to which they are entitled. Unless we put the worth of every person in the forefront of our policies instead of having some economic goals as our sole guiding light we can look forward to a situation of continuing social disintegration. The anger which builds up in the unemployed not only finds individual expression, as with descent into the drug culture, the increasing suicide rate and the tension generated within households which leads to the breakdown of many families, but also has an overall social dimension where contempt for persons and property, and ultimately our political institutions, as Senator Foreman pointed out, is a very real danger.

This is particularly the case with youth unemployment. Approximately one in five of our 15 to 19-year-olds cannot find employment despite their best efforts . In Tasmania about three people out of every ten in that age group cannot find employment and the duration of unemployment is becoming longer and longer. This is a point which was well made by Senator Giles in her contribution to this debate. The social security system devised by this Government is very ill- matched to the growing social problems that are emerging. It is based on an unemployment benefit which was originally intended as a short-term maintenance measure to see a person through a relatively sporadic short period of unemployment. Extended periods of unemployment were not thought of, yet the distress caused by extended periods of poverty is very real. We find that the average duration of unemployment for 15 to 19-year-olds is 18 weeks. For persons 20 years and over it is some 36 weeks, that is 9 months. The financial constraints on a household created by extended unemployment is not in any way ameliorated by the type of social security system support that we offer.

The social security system is ill-designed to meet the fact that in the case of a family breakdown situation prevailing in society, exacerbated by unemployment creating insecurity and tensions within the household, there is less readiness, on the part of families, to provide the support needed for the young unemployed, the young school leaver. Whilst our social security system is premised on the basis that accommodation, food, health care and allowance for travelling whilst seeking employment, which is an expensive pursuit, are available from within the family, the social situation is quite different. Many young school leavers find themselves living and existing outside the family situation and therefore the support that we offer them should be much more than it is. But with the Government party room full of Senator Jessop's type I expect that that response will not be forthcoming. For a senator to say that 20 per cent of the unemployed in Australia are unemployable is to say that 96,000 of our fellow Australians-as officially tallied let alone the hidden unemployed-are lacking in skills. But more than that, there is an overtone of their being so socially inadequate that they are unemployable. To think that that is the response from the Government party room, from the Government honourable senator put up to take part in this debate, is indeed frightening. However, it is not surprising.

An extremely good paper was put out by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the National Employers Industrial Council-not the most radical body in Australia-in August 1978. Concerning youth unemployment, it stated:

For far too long we as a nation have conveniently ignored the plight of the young. However, it is strongly suggested that by our continued failure to recognise and understand the long-term consequences of continuing to neglect the employment problems confronting this generation, we are establishing the groundwork for future social and economic instability, disruption and dislocation.

It was suggested by those bodies that those in government as well as industry leaders, trade union officials and educationalists find, in a common meeting, an appreciation and understanding of the social and economic changes taking place and of the impact those changes are having on the employment position of youth. Those bodies-the Confederation of Australian Industry and the National Employers Industrial Council-asked all groups within the Australian community which had a concern to come together to try to come up with a rational response to youth unemployment. Yet the Government's reaction, only over the last fortnight, to Mr Bob Hawke's plea in the other place to set up a joint committee-a plea which he made in the late 1980s-to examine these problems was rejected out of hand. The proposal to set up a bipartisan joint committee of this Parliament, with representatives from both chambers is the sort of environment which we all know from experience is conducive to rational discussion and well-considered proposals coming forward-was rejected by this Government. That is not surprising ; it is in line with the Government's following through of the razor gang's recommendation that the Commonwealth Employment Service no longer obtain statistics on the local impact of unemployment. This, as I will argue later, would be extremely important in any rational attempt to combat unemployment. We must look for positive policies to create employment, not those which merely try to ameliorate the effects of unemployment.

Certainly the Labor Government, in 1983 and beyond, will take such steps as are necessary and would be expected from a Labor Government to ensure that programs are undertaken which will help to create and generate jobs. This is the task which as a community we must set ourselves. I was pleased to see that Senator Jessop, apparently with ill effect, claims to have been advocating within his party room public capital works. There is no doubt that public capital works have the largest multiplier effect of any form of public expenditure on economic activity and employment. For example, increased spending on public housing would stimulate a depressed industry and depressed regions, begin to reduce housing commission waiting lists and contribute to easing pressure on housing prices. There would be no difficulty in identifying other socially responsible spending programs.

It is true that as the economy would expand under a Labor Government's expansionary fiscal and monetary policies there would be a slight inflationary effect. That is why I agreed, in the course of Senator Jessop's remarks, that in order to combat that inflationary trend within the community we would need a proper package of anti-inflationary measures. Whereas this Government pursues an unjust, anti-inflationary policy which is utterly and absurdly ineffective-it combats inflation by raising the price of health and so on-the Australian Labor Party, as a substitute for that and as part of the package of anti-inflationary measures, would seek acceptance within the Australian community of a comprehensive, equitable, voluntary prices and incomes policy. I believe that by that means we might have, as I say, such an equitable and comprehensive prices and incomes policy that some of the fears of Senator Jessop, of escalating wage payments, within our community could be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that policy ever worked anywhere else in the Western world?

—My point is that we will not try to use government legislative or constitutional powers to achieve this. It will be voluntary. If it is voluntary and in conjunction with a resuscitated Prices Justification Tribunal I believe that the sort of support which we might hope for from the unions in particular will be forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few moments remaining to me I would not want to leave Senator Martyr with the obvious retort: 'Oh well, there goes Senator Tate on behalf of the Labor Party again talking about capital expenditure with all the consequences that that may have within the economy'. Indeed, that is not a sufficient solution to the problem of job generation. I commend to the Senate a book which has been published only this week-certainly I hope that Government Ministers will have a look at it-entitled 'Job-Generation' by Tom O'Brien. In very simple terms the book outlines the following proposal:
. . . a government sponsored community development program intended to activate local communities to generate new jobs within their own areas.

Hence the need for the CES statistics on the impact of unemployment in particular areas. He proposes the formation of a community enterprise foundation based on local government areas with local government sponsorship, but with a very real input from the local business community. We would be creating a situation in which small business in particular-which is the real generator of jobs within our economy-had access to what might be termed 'a multi-dimensional management consultancy operation'. That is a large term for a situation wherein within each local community one would have a local small business, in particular -entrepreneurs-in a community enterprise foundation group interacting with community leadership from local government, and State and Federal government people with their expertise having an input. The group would enable small business not only to become more aware of the job opportunities which are represented by the job statistics at the moment in a fairly negative way but also-this is contained in Tom O'Brien's proposal-to have access to venture finance. The proposal would also open up the trading banks to a more realistic apportioning of their funds to the creation of job opportunities within the small business sector. I regret very much that I am not able to detail that proposal. I read it only at lunch time. The book has only just become available. I believe the proposal has within it the seeds for a very positive co-operative effort with private enterprise and local communities to create jobs within local districts. I believe that with that sort of support, plus Federal Government spending on capital works and a more compassionate responsive attitude by government to unemployment, we will reach a stage where this sort of matter of public importance will not be necessary in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I represent the Australian Democrats in the debate on this matter of public importance. Honourable senators will note that I am speaking in this debate and not Senator John Siddons, who has pursued this policy area since he came into this place with tremendous energy, experience and ability. It is only because of the other very heavy policy areas bearing on him-that is, industrial relations and the economy generally-that I now have assumed this portfolio responsibility in which I will do my poor best compared with him. However, it is an area of interest to me. The Australian Democrats believe that any government that obstructs the basic human drive to work which has been inculcated into our young , be it natural or not, over many generations and which is a major part of our social and cultural traditions, does so at our peril. That is the basic major consideration behind any debate of this kind. It implies, therefore, that any government has a basic responsibility to the people of a country trained in that tradition to provide employment opportunities for all its citizens who may wish to work. Indeed, that is basic to Australian Democrat policy. I think we listed that as one of the major considerations-indeed, the primary consideration-of our economic policy. We believe that it is with reason. It is something to which the community would subscribe and which all reasonable citizens would support.
—Is that the policy that began four score and seven years ago?

—No. It is the policy which-unlike Liberal Party policies-was determined by ballot about four years ago but which has been modified and adjusted since. Our policies are constantly under review. But Senator Peter Baume makes a very good point. Nothing has happened on the Government side. The Government has done nothing whatsoever to ameliorate unemployment that would cause us to change our policy. It only emphasises that it becomes increasingly necessary with the passing years of Liberal Party inadequacy in this direction. It has become increasingly obvious that this Government has been not only unable but also apparently unwilling to provide the opportunity to get Australians back to work. I think that is one of the most serious indictments that can be made against it.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment statistics continually rise and have risen again recently. The January 1982 figures show that 6.5 per cent of the population is unemployed. The figure of 72,800 for youth unemployment-or, as Senator Tate mentioned slightly more than one-fifth of the population -or 21.2 per cent of the total youth employment potential is, I think, a gross indictment not only in economic terms, although of course in the area of unemployment we have a billion dollar economic problem, a billion dollar millstone around the neck of the national economy, but also in social terms. It is an appalling consequence. It is an interesting figure-one in five. We have created, through our actions and inabilities, a fifth column of considerable potential. We have said that four out of five young people who have passed through the educational process for good or for bad are entitled to become a part of lawful and socially acceptable objectives. We have said that one in five is not to have that opportunity. By failing to provide reasonable national facilities for retraining and returning confidence to the young unemployed who have never worked we have almost said that this one in five discrimination is a sort of permanent thing in the society.

This is why I agree with Senator Tate. I find it deeply disturbing that Senator Jessop should get up in this chamber and say that 20 per cent of the work force appears to be unemployable. I suggest that that statement is an indictment of the system rather than those people. I do not believe that what he has said is true. If it were true I think he and the Government would need to look very carefully at their objectives and at their rationale to see whether or not they had some responsibility for that situation or some duty to do something effective about it, which they are not doing now and show no signs of doing. It is not good enough for a government senator to get up here and merely say that that is the situation as though this huge number of Australians were a sub-class or separate class to whom we have no responsibility whatsoever. I do not know what Senator Jessop thinks the eventual fate of these people should be. Does he think they should continue to exist in a state of limbo and do nothing? That will not happen. Of course it will not happen. As in other countries, if our young people are not given the opportunity to take part in socially acceptable objectives sooner or later somebody will come to them and use their natural drive to support something in a wrong and improper sense. That is what happened in Germany and in Italy when the dictatorships arose. It was the young to whom Hitler and Mussolini went and said: 'Here. They give you nothing'. Their Governments, like our present Government said: 'Here we are. We have something to give you. We give you hope for the future. We give you new objectives'. If we are fool enough to think that what happened under those Governments could not happen here we are very stupid indeed. Of course, this does not apply only to the young.

I cannot enter into a debate like this without saying that there is another area of unemployment which I find even more traumatic. People in their forties and fifties have come to me. They have worked well for this country all their lives and have no reason whatsoever to be regarded as unemployable. In many cases they have lost their jobs, to the regret of their employers, and cannot get another job. They want another job. Not only do they not have a job but they know only too well that they will never get one. These people in their 40s and 50s should be a major source of concern to this country, and the growth of bitterness amongst those people also should be of concern to all of us.

I think it is also rather serious that it is becoming increasingly difficult for young people to get full time jobs. Therefore, they tend to go for part time jobs. This is creating, in my experience and from what I have heard back from the community, a very unhealthy situation. Because of the competitive nature of the job market most of the new teenage part time workers are employed in menial jobs. They are literally becoming the untouchables of our society. Anything is good enough for them. They are the people who do such monotonous jobs as packing , wrapping, cleaning and washing windows. Sometimes they are lucky enough to get mentally elevating jobs as cashiers, sales assistants, waitresses and, of course , often enough as labourers. These jobs contain virtually no training aspect. I think this is one of the serious things about them. They are not jobs that form the beginning of a career path.

The young people who are forced into them through sheer economic necessity and who are forced to accept whatever conditions an employer wants to put on them I feel cannot be regarded as being very different from those who are unemployed. This has an effect on their view of the future and the ability of the society which has nurtured and educated them. I think it is reasonable that they should ask and expect that society to give them what they want within reason if they are prepared to work for it. We are creating an unhealthy situation in this country in which it is increasingly possible for young people to be exploited as cheap labour. That is, indeed, happening to an enormous extent. Evidence has also shown that as well as being particularly exploitable, young people are most vulnerable to the effects of unemployment because school leavers who have no history of employment will in most cases not even be considered for a job. This is happening right up to the highly qualified people in the community. Most of last year's graduates in social work, who worked for four years in universities to get their degree, have not yet found a job. I know this because my daughter is one of them. Fortunately she was trained previously as a nurse and she has gone back to that career. It is useful work but she did, after all, do four years study to be a social worker. As far as this Government is concerned that is of no value, no importance and no consequence; it is good enough for those people merely to do anything else. Most of the ones who have had no alternative training, I imagine, will soon be working as waitresses, cashiers and checkout girls in supermarkets. That is what the Government has wished on this society.

Because young unemployed people have little money their usual sources of entertainment are often unavailable. This is not right. There is no reason, in an affluent society such as ours, for these people to be forced into inevitable constraints. Because they are not given any opportunity to find work, life is made miserable and uncomfortable for them in every possible way. Their self- confidence is destroyed through this process. They lose contact with their friends and boredom and frustration set in. This leads to drug and alcohol abuse and, in the extreme, attempted suicide or, in some cases, unfortunately, actual suicide.

In our society acceptance as an adult is based to a large extent on financial independence. Our media constantly drum into young people all the things they should want to have. I do not necessarily agree with the consumer society, but I think it is very wrong to have made those points to our young people and then suddenly at the end of their schooling for them to find that they are deprived of those things which they felt they reasonably had a right to expect. Due to economic conditions prevailing in the country some young people are forced to survive on $36 a week, and adults on not much more. This presents and creates further difficulties, and for some can create actual poverty.

As recently as last week the Australian Democrats met with a delegation from the Under-18 Income Campaign. I was not involved but Senator Chipp assisted in the launching of a publication that those unemployed youths put together. In the publication they listed their requests which included increasing their benefits from the present $36 week to the adult rate. As a result of discussions with these young people Senator Chipp, on behalf of the Democrats suggested that perhaps with the Australian Labor Party we could introduce a private member's Bill somehow to find some way to substantially increase the benefit. It is too low; it has not been increased and it is causing actual hardship. I do not think it is right and proper that it should do so. Alternatively, the Senate could take the initiative and pass a motion requesting the House of Representatives to introduce such a Bill, which is certainly by far the better way this could be done, if indeed we could achieve that.

Senator Jessop mentioned 36,700 available jobs. Are they really available to the young people who cannot get work? Of course they are not! I have talked to people who have these jobs available. A lot of these jobs require experience, and there is no way in the world in which young people can apply for them and hope to get them. Many young people have in fact already applied for them and have been turned down. Senator Jessop castigates these young people as being unemployable because they cannot get jobs. He thinks they are happy enough to continue on the dole, but I do not believe that. I believe those ones are very much the minority and I believe there are young people who have rationalised their position perhaps to the extent to which they believe they are happier on the dole, which is a very different thing. In other words, their self-confidence and desire to do something have been destroyed so effectively by the system that they no longer want to try. Do we abandon them completely in the future? No, of course not. Even these people might respond to an imaginative, flexible, compassionate and voluntary program designed expressly to help them. This is what we do not have in this country, in spite of the tremendous efforts mustered by individual communities and people in the Community Youth Support Scheme area. I commend them in every possible respect. But we should have a national program in this area.

I believe most young people want a job and not this continuing situation in which their self-respect is continually eroded until the time comes when they no longer have the confidence to apply for jobs. They believe they will be told yet again that the job has gone to somebody with work experience. I think we can identify at this stage two major problems. One is a lack of self-esteem and self -confidence amongst these young people. The second is the difficulty in getting work if they have not even had work experience. This becomes a catch-22 situation indeed. I have discussed the matter with many young people of this kind in drop-in centres throughout Australia but mostly in New South Wales. I have met with informal groups and also with individuals, and they confirm these two problems and others. Another problem is the lack of confidence in the work situation generally and the lack of ability to compete with prospective co- workers who already have work experience. This may be a key to Senator Jessop's complaint that these people do not stay in jobs very long. Many of the young people I spoke with were, as it were, pre-programmed for failure. They believe that even if they get a job they may well fail at it. Such feelings, of course, tend to be self-fulfilling. I think everyone of us would know or would have heard of instances in which this is the case.

What then, in the view of these young people, is the answer? I do not have time to deal with this aspect to any extent, but basically they need some work in which they could be involved with other young people like themselves. I believe one would have to be very cynical indeed not to believe that most young human beings feel they would like to be of use and value. This is a mainstay of human self-esteem and it is an element in this situation. The so-called young unemployables want to feel they are doing something of value and that the work they are engaged in is a meaningful contribution to the country. If we neglect this latent appeal to patriotism and a sense of purpose I believe indeed we are fools. As I said, if the society does not use these drives, sooner or later some anti-social group will use them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to speak in this debate, I suppose, because I am probably the only one here who has recently been unemployed, and I cannot say that that was totally unexpected. Anyway, I found congenial employment about 12 months ago. I have a great deal of sympathy for people who are out of work. I think it should go without saying that I would have had a great deal of sympathy for them even if I had not had that experience . Unemployment happens frequently, and it has always happened. I think I should begin my remarks by making five points about the current unemployment figures which seem to have been some of the basis for this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the movement in full time unemployment in February indicates an easing in the labour market. Nevertheless, too much emphasis should not be placed on the figures for one month. February, along with December and January, is traditionally a high month for unemployment due to seasonal factors. The figures should be considered in the context of the slowing but still solid growth in employment which has occurred in recent months. Over the 12 months to January 1982 employment increased by 1.6 per cent. The full time employment rate of 7 per cent was higher than the rates recorded in February 1981, 1980 and 1979, but lower than the rate of 7.3 per cent recorded in February 1978. I hope that Senator Foreman, in particular, takes note of that. The fourth point is that the increase in full time unemployment during February 1982 occurred amongst adults, but there was a lower than expected decline in teenage unemployment. Over the 12 months to February 1982 the increase in adult full time unemployment was 37,200 or 16.1 per cent. This compares with the rise in teenage full time unemployment of 8,900 or 7 per cent over the same period.

Those five points and an understanding of what they mean are absolutely essential to the conduct of this debate. The Government must reject solutions which will empty the Treasury or run the country into graver deficit than it is in now. For the Opposition, however, the whole subjet is timeless. It is an everlasting essay. It is scarcely an original subject for a matter of public importance as it has been gone over so often under other headings in recent weeks, months and years. Ever since 1975 the Opposition has said the same thing time and again. The Opposition is asserting once again that the Fraser Government is useless. But it never gives any reasons for this assertion. In two Houses I have heard the same argument time without number and still no reasons are given. There is no doubt in my mind that Senator Scott and Senator Jessop, in their very worthy contributions to the debate, answered every one of these assertions, as Government speakers always do. Senator Tate said it was rubbish to generalise. What on earth has the Opposition been doing but generalising? He joined Senator Foreman-this was a marriage of hyperbole and exaggeration if ever there was one-in saying that national crisis could be linked to social devastation. What sort of gross exaggerations are these? But we are accustomed to hearing such gross exaggerations every day.

Let us look at a particular aspect of what the Opposition is saying. Why do we have darkened corridors in this building today? We have them because of the actions of a few militant trade unionists in New South Wales. We know that their actions have grave consequences for their fellow unionists. The militants do not care about the consequences of their actions; they do not care that they cause unemployment among fellow unionists or dislocation and inconvenience for everyone. Some unionists do care. I will quote what the Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Union in New South Wales and Mr Wran have said. They back up- no matter how the Opposition may not like it-what the Government has been saying for years. Mr Joe Thompson of the Vehicle Builders Employees Union warned that the present crisis would have disastrous consequences for New South Wales. He stated:
Those power workers in dispute should remember that a lot of fellow unionists are going to suffer if zoning is introduced.

Mr Wran, in an attack which the Australian Financial Review described as savage, warned the New South Wales Parliament that, unless the damaging bans and limitations were lifted immediately by the unions, the State's three million workers faced a four day working week starting on Monday. He has made attacks on other unions for the selfishness which brings about difficulty and dislocation for all citizens and causes unemployment among their own number. What sort of effect is this dispute having in this country today? Mr Wran and Mr Thompson have indicated the effect on the whole employment situation. Senator Scott made the point very clearly that these irresponsible actions have a drastic effect on the employment situation in Australia. The final word, of course, on trade union irresponsibility generally in these matters comes from another oracle who is vastly experienced. I refer to Mr Bob Hawke who presently enjoys a position in the other place. He has said:
. . . I have made it clear that, at times, the actions of unions have not been wise.
At another time he said:
. . . that doesn't mean that I endorse every strike that takes place. Some of them are silly . . .
At another time he stated:
Let me make my position quite clear. There is no doubt that some strikes are not justified . . .
Finally-this is the prince of quotations-Mr Hawke said:
Firstly, let me concede that at times I believe unions do some bloody stupid things and I have said so publicly.

The words I have quoted came from people who know what they are talking about. It is quite clear to me that Mr Hawke, Mr Wran and Mr Thompson are all experienced in the labour movement and the trade unions. They know the drastic consequences that the actions of irresponsible trade unionists are having on the total situation in Australia. They are having an effect on the unemployment rate .

I now make a few points about Senator Foreman's contribution. He accused the Government of getting rid of the embarrassing Commonwealth Employment Service figures. The only reason the Government is using figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics is that they are far more accurate and representative of the exact situation. The CES figures gave a completely distorted view of the employment situation. I use the word 'employment' advisedly. I did not say ' unemployment' situation quite deliberately. Senator Foreman talked about the hidden unemployment figures. Of course they are hidden. That is a good word to use because if there be such a thing as hidden unemployment-I am not saying that there is not-not a great deal of hard evidence is available about it. What evidence there is, once again, is subject to gross exaggeration for quite obvious political reasons. Senator Foreman quoted Mr Hawke as an authority. I too have quoted Mr Hawke as an authority but not in the same vein as Senator Foreman. He then accused the Government of being penny-pinching. He referred to the penny-pinching policies of the Fraser Government. This Government is so penny-pinching that it has kept up the level of unemployment benefit to those who should be in just receipt of them and it has kept up the Community Youth Support Scheme in spite of a lot of opposition from its back bench. I am not entirely in favour of CYSS but others in the party have a different idea and it is their writ that carries.

Everything that the Government could possibly do to ameliorate unemployment has been done. Yet we are accused of penny-pinching and lack of generosity. If that is an implied attack on the Government's monetary policy I have to say that that is the salvation of this country. If we succumb to the temptation of using the printing press to get ourselves out of trouble we will be in the same difficulty as the Whitlam Government was in and we will fall the same way. Honourable senators should make no mistake about that. It is the greatest achievement of the Fraser Government to resist that temptation. Senator Foreman said that we have had a slow down in employment, that there is no hope of growth and that this situation will lead to vast youth unemployment. He said also that it could lead to looting and gang warfare. I do not know where endemic sectarianism came into it, but I think at one stage that was the point he was trying to make. Of course once again, these are typical and gross exaggerations. There is nothing like that in this country. Unless people on the other side are prepared to stir the pot there will be nothing like it. Honourable senators on the Opposition side know it as well as I do. The situation in this country is nothing like the situation in others. Indeed, I keep on saying that this country is far more fortunate than elsewhere. This is not to neglect or reject the situation of the unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not mean to say that we are not concerned about those things.

—I share the honourable senator's concern. Let us do something positive about it. Let us not talk a whole lot of exaggerated rubbish which will only cause difficulty in the country and will not solve the problems that we both concede exist. I am reminded also that we keep blaming Mr Whitlam. I thought we had left that behind a long time ago. I was privileged this morning to hear Mr Whitlam speaking about another subject about which, when it is revealed, some of the Opposition will not be too pleased. We will leave that matter for another occasion. I do not blame Mr Whitlam for anything. Mr Whitlam is now a retired Prime Minister. He is of no concern to me in anything to do with the matters that are before us all today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles raised some matters, the most important one being about a proper concern at the lack of opportunity available for youth. I point out to Senator Giles-again she may not like to hear it-that there is some truth in the assertion that large numbers of married women who are employed deny the opportunity of jobs to their daughters. I am not saying that this is the whole story; it is certainly a part of it. I understand the necessity for some married women to work. I wanted to bring some sanity into this debate, in reply to the scaremongering of the Opposition. The preliminary employment statistics for February 1982 are worrying but they are no cause for panic as the Opposition is trying to suggest. The unemployment figures for February show by no means a satisfactory result but it is unwise to place too much emphasis on one month's figures. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
