SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The large claim that is made by Senator Evans for his Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments ) Bill is that it constitutes the only presently realistic solution to what he describes as the institutional problems inherent in our present Constitution. He referred to it as 'a principled solution to the problem of 1975'. The Bill proposes an elaborate and drastic reordering and restructuring of the Australian constitutional system. If adopted, the proposal would involve shifts of a fundamental kind in our institutions of representative and responsible government which would become entrenched in our political system.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans's Bill, if it were successful, would result in a major change in the whole power structure of the parliamentary system resulting in a major downgrading of the Senate and a House of Representatives in which the government of the day would be either an all-powerful government and immune from accountability to the people for its full term if a stable system were to continue or, if stable majorities were not available, a weak government which would have to bargain from day to day for its continued survival. I think we can all understand and support the need to have more stability and continuity in our political environment. However, Senator Evans's Bill offers no guarantee of achieving this. Under this Bill the proposed fixed term is one for three years only. In fact, the average length of time between elections since 1949 has been two years, four and a half months. The Bill would at most add only an extra seven or eight months to the average parliamentary term. Even this is not certain, since the Bill would still allow early elections to be held. The amendment foreshadowed by Senator Evans, that a parliament elected after such an early election would only serve out the remainder of the fixed term, would mean that where an early election is held it would be followed immediately by yet another early election. In effect, early elections may well be multiplied.

In the Government's view the real answer to achieving more continuity and stability may well be a maximum four-year term for the Parliament, as was adopted by a two-thirds majority in the recent State referendum in New South Wales. It has been ably argued that the present term of three years is too short for good government. Governments are inhibited from long term planning and have not the time to see through their programs and their effects. The needs of modern, complex societies are such that programs need time to bear fruit. If parliaments could run to four years as a maximum then, on average, parliaments would be likely to last more than three years, even under our existing provisions. In reality, Senator Evans's Bill is not about more stable government and fewer elections-whatever he might say on that point. Its real purpose is to offer what turns out to be a partisan solution to the so-called problems of 1975 . It is an attempt to deal with these problems by a drastic reduction in the power of the Senate. People, both inside and outside Parliament, therefore need to understand that Senator Evans's Bill is not really concerned about fixed terms as such.

I now return to the whole discussion of the fixed term concept. The best example of a fixed term parliament is provided by the Constitution of the United States of America. Indeed, Senator Evans has followed a notable feature of that example in determining that an election will be held on a certain day every three years. However, two major features of that system, of course, are not dealt with in this Bill. Firstly, the United States Constitution makes absolutely no provision for the dissolution of Congress during its term. It is pertinent to note that congressional elections occur every two years. Secondly, the United States Constitution provides also for a fixed term Executive and the election of the Executive by a separate vote of the people. The proponents of engrafting a fixed term parliament on a system of responsible government are faced with what I believe to be an insoluble dilemma. On the one hand, they are obliged to evolve some provisions to resolve a potential conflict between the Executive and the body which creates it and to which it is responsible -that is, the parliament. On the other hand, the more attempts are made to provide a resolution for that conflict the less the result contains the elements of the fixed term concept.

For the Australian Constitution with its powerful Senate the dilemma is even more acute. Indeed, Senator Evans's odyssey on this subject is a good example of this dilemma. First of all, Senator Evans had to provide for some method of resolving the conflict in the House of Representatives and he chose the no confidence procedure. He then had to provide for the conflict between the houses and he retained the double dissolution procedure in a modified form. However, he then discovered that a government which desired an election could easily manipulate these provisions in order to achieve its purpose. Senator Evans now proposes to build in what he calls a 'disincentive' for a government otherwise bent on an early election. The so-called disincentive is that a parliament elected after an early election will only serve out the remainder of the fixed term. However, a government bent on an election to resolve its conflict with either house of the parliament-the conflict may be in either House-is not likely to be deterred by this ingenuous proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ingenuous or ingenious?

—The word is ingenuous. I am quite clear on that. The result of the so-called disincentive would only be more elections, which it is the very purpose of the fixed term concept to avoid. If Senator Evans really wanted to ensure a fixed term for the House of Representatives he would have to completely emasculate the powers of the Senate, not only over money Bills but also in respect of all its legislative powers and, if retained at all, retain the Senate as some form of antipodean House of Lords, a solution which is not politicaly feasible. On the other hand, if Senator Evans wanted to provide for all the possible conflicts which could arise between a government in the House of Representatives, he would have to provide for so many occasions when a Prime Minister can seek an election that any concept of a fixed term would disappear. A glaring omission from this Bill in this respect is that it provides no guarantee that a government would be able to secure supply in the House of Representatives. A government could be put in the position of having to negotiate quite unreasonable terms from a minority in that chamber which was not prepared to install the Opposition in government or itself face the risk of an election. Under Senator Evans's Bill only a formal vote of no confidence, which may be withheld for all sorts of reasons, would free the Governor-General to dismiss the Prime Minister or dissolve the House of Representatives if supply were not able to be secured from that House.

SPEECH.PARA: The fixed term concept could, on the evidence of the American experience, produce a situation in which a government could not implement the program upon which it had been elected by the Australian people. It could produce a situation in which there would be 'lame duck' administrations which were unable to grapple with national problems in an effective way. They would be 'lame ducks' because, while their tenure of office would run on, their capacity to act would be crippled unless an appeal to the electorate were possible. When all the possibilities are seriously considered rather than glossed over, it becomes clear that the adoption of a fixed term concept would be, as one political scientist has observed, a leap into, if not the dark, then at least one of the twilight zones of constitution making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—It was Professor Colin Hughes. I understand that his view has not been published. The more one studies the concept the more it becomes apparent that it is irreconcilable with the system of responsible government. That is not surprising because such a system demands that there should be no basic conflict between the parliament and the Executive and that if such a conflict cannot be resolved within the parliament it must be resolved by the people. The history of parliamentary democracy clearly shows that this method, although not foolproof, is the most satisfactory system which has been devised. In its 1959 report the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review stated that the right of the Crown to dissolve the House of Representatives before it had served its full term is necessary for the maintenance of responsible government. Sir Owen Dixon underlined and elaborated this principle in a speech entitled ' Government under the American Constitution' given in 1944, immediately after returning to Australia from the position of Australian Ambassador to Washington. He was in a very unique vantage position to observe the differences-he was very interested in the differences-between the Australian system and the American system. He applied his great intellect and experience in considering these differences. In his conclusion he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We, under our conception of democracy, so far from separating the executive and the legislature, insist on the dependence of the Cabinet upon Parliament. We insist too that if a difficulty arises between the executive government and Parliament, it shall be resolved by an appeal to the people, and we place on the representative of the Sovereign the responsibility of saying whether the case is one for the dissolution of Parliament and a general election. This we can do because we have proudly preserved the monarchy as the apex of our constitutional system. In the United States the President is elected for four years-a fixed period. Congress cannot be dissolved.

The fixed term rule must, if it means anything, involve destroying the power of the Governor-General-which this Bill does-acting in accordance with recognised conventions and practices to dissolve the House of Representatives. This would remove the means by which relations between the electorate, parliament and the government can, consistently with the principles of responsible government, be adjusted.

There remains only one other argument in support of the fixed term concept and that is the objection that a Prime Minister can obtain an unfair advantage by calling a snap election. This argument is based on the theory that a Prime Minister always has an election in his pocket. However, this theory does not square with what Governors-General have said on the topic and overlooks the realities of the situation. Any Prime Minister has to justify an early election not only to the Governor-General but also to the electorate, an experience which two Premiers of South Australia have learned to their cost over the last decade.

However, let us look at the so-called problem in the Federal sphere. Since the end of World War II there have been six Federal elections that could be described as early elections. Three of those were double dissolutions to resolve the deadlock between the two houses that occurred in 1951, 1974 and 1975. The early election that was sought and granted in 1963 was based on the need for a more secure majority than that provided by one member at a time that was regarded as one of international crisis. The remaining elections were in 1955 and 1977. A number of factors were relied upon in each of these cases but in each case the Prime Minister, in advising the Governor-General, relied upon bringing the Senate elections and the House of Representative elections back into phase following the dislocation of elections for those houses brought about by double dissolutions in 1951 and 1975. As I have said, in all of those cases sound reasons had to be advanced by a Prime Minister for seeking a dissolution. The fact of the matter is that there may be good reasons-other than simple political advantage-why a government may wish to have a fresh commission from the electors or why an early election should be required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you planning one for this year?

—I hope that I am dealing with this matter in a detached way, as Senator Evans has always done. I am suggesting some reasons which may be regarded, for the purpose of this argument, as academic. I have said that there may be good reasons. I mention some that come readily to mind: Where party defectors seek to install another government without an election; where the House of Representatives is unstable or unworkable; where the Government's policies are being continually frustrated by the parliament-in either House; where the Government wishes to seek the mandate for some new important measure or policy; where there is a gross and patent breach of the law which cannot be dealt with adequately by the judicature, or where there is other conduct amounting to a gross and patent breach of the basic provisions of the constitutional system. I do not believe that I am alone in thinking that the advantages to the democratic system of being able to have an early election may have been underrated while the advantages to the party in power of being able to call a snap election have been exaggerated.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have dealt with the fixed term parliament concept. I turn now to the objects of Senator Evans's Bill. The real thrust of the Bill is not its fixed term aspect but its attack on the powers and status of the Senate. The changes proposed in the Bill include abolishing the Senate's power under section 53 of the Constitution to block Bills appropriating revenue or moneys or imposing taxation, abolishing the existing powers of the Governor-General to dissolve the House of Representatives under section 5 of the Constitution before the expiration of three years and abolishing any discretion the Governor-General has to dissolve both Houses where there is a deadlock under section 57. Under the Bill the abolition is not limited to appropriations for the ordinary annual services of the Government, commonly referred to as Supply. All financial measures passed by the House of Representatives would become law in 30 days, whatever the Senate might say or do.

SPEECH.PARA: The foreshadowed amendment that Senator Evans unveiled last Thursday constitutes a retreat from this extreme position but the Senate would still be denied the power to reject what he calls 'crucially important appropriation and taxation measures the passage of which is indispensible to a government's capacity to continue to govern'. That is a quote from the statement Senator Evans tabled in the Senate in the shortest speech that he ever made or is likely to make. It is a very significant statement. I am sorry to have to provoke him to lengthy explanations which no doubt he will give in the Senate on a number of future occasions, but I have a number of questions in relation to the statement. The first is: What is meant by it? What are the criteria to decide what is crucial? Who is to decide? Is it to be the government of the day? Is it intended that the High Court should decide after the event whether a Bill is one that the Senate could amend or reject? It certainly appears to me that if a provision of such magnitude is contemplated in our Constitution the only appropriate body to decide that would be the High Court. But, as Senator Evans said, we will see. We will no doubt hear from him as well with respect to those problems. I mentioned this because it really is a vital issue. As proposed by him, it is a very vague issue which needs a great deal of further development.

In whatever form this provision is to be expressed, the thrust of the Bill, with its refinements, is directed against the Senate. If the Bill were to become part of the Constitution it would be possible for a government with a secure majority in the House of Representatives to hold on to office for its full term even in extreme circumstances that might otherwise require an early election. Such circumstances might exist, for example, where a Government was acting in gross and patent breach of basic principles of the constitutional system or in admitted or proved breaches of the law. On the other hand, there is no guarantee that a government in control of the House of Representatives could not manipulate the exceptions to the fixed term rule to obtain an early election if it wished to do so. Thus, the possibility of a double dissolution is to be preserved. Its retention negates the fixed term concept. A double dissolution would be able to be engineered by the majority party in the House of Representatives where the Senate was of a different political complexion. It could create a deadlock between the two Houses by promoting a Bill that it knew the Senate would be bound to reject. The Government could than move at once to an election, one that would breach not only the fixed term of the House of Representatives but also the fixed term of the Senate.

But even apart from this possibility, the provisions of the Bill requiring a formal vote of no confidence before the government can gain an immediate election offer no guarantee against an early election before the government's full term expires. It cannot be assumed that a government would not be prepared to bring about an early election by resort to this sort of mechanism. This is exactly what happened in West Germany in 1972. Under the West German Constitution the term of the lower House of Parliament is fixed, subject to an early dissolution if the Chancellor is unable to obtain a vote of confidence in his Government. The similarity of this concept and what is in this Bill will be apparent, the only difference being that while the West German Constitution employs the mechanism of a defeated vote of confidence to bring about an early election, the proposal now before us employs the mechanism of a vote of no confidence.

Chancellor Brandt announced in June 1972 that he intended to hold a general election later that year-about 10 months before the end of the Parliament's fixed term. In September that year he initiated the process by moving a vote of confidence in his own Government-a vote which he was determined to lose. In his autobiography Willie Brandt: People and Politics; the Years 1960-1975 he described the process in the following terms:

My request for a vote of confidence under Article 68 of the Basic Law was laid before the Bundestag on 20 September and rejected-according to plan-two days later. To make doubly sure, I and a number of my colleagues abstained. Before the vote, I declared that it should really be sought, not in parliament, but from the sovereign electors of the country. Those who had switched their allegiance were fulfilling a veto function. 'The electors can decide whether to confirm that veto or, in accordance with my expectations, set it aside'. The Federal President dissolved the Bundestag and set new elections for 19 November.

It should be clear from this account that any fixed term proposal that endeavours to accommodate the need for an occasional early dissolution involves a delusion. Under the present proposal it would be possible for a government, in appropriate circumstances, to engineer a no confidence resolution against itself as a technicality to bring about an early election in which it could go to the people as the government. It would also remain possible to engineer a double dissolution, of course, as I have already said.

As a solution to the 1975 situation the Bill turns out to be a partisan one. It involves abolition of the Senate's power to block Supply. Of course, I am not sure whether, in the light of recent utterances by leaders of the Australian Labor Party, the Bill in fact represents their current policy, but I suppose we must take it as it has been introduced. However, let me assure the Parliament and the people of Australia that, in contrast to the vacillations of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats on this point, the Government's policy on these matters is based on consistent and enduring principles and not on political expediency. We are committed to the co-equal and co-ordinate status of the Senate. We do not shrink from accountability to the electorate whenever Westminster principles indicate there should be an early election. We have also already indicated a preparedness to consider improvements within that system, as , for example, under the Court proposal adopted at the Perth Constitutional Convention in 1978.

Let me recall to the Senate some features of that proposal. The Court proposal would preserve the power of the Senate to withhold Supply. The proposal improves the present method of resolving deadlocks over Supply in a number of significant ways. It would, as developed, prevent unconstitutional tacking of extraneous items to Supply measures. It would also remove a major source of disruption which would otherwise result from the exercise of the Senate's power to block Supply, by ensuring the availability of authority to expend public funds until elections are held for both Houses of Parliament and a new Parliament appropriates funds. It would effectively streamline the present procedure to dissolve both Houses of Parliament and ensure that both Houses faced the electors in the event of a Senate withholding Supply. It would eliminate the need for the Governor-General to intervene in any deadlock between the two Houses over Supply. It would do this by requiring and not merely enabling both Houses to be dissolved.

However, other solutions may be possible and the Government has an open mind on the matter. Thus, if we are to talk of 'realistic solutions' obviously consideration has to be given to the possibility of extending the term of Parliament from three to four years; not as part of a fixed term project but as allowing the possibility of Parliament extending to four years as in New South Wales. Such a proposal merits consideration. It might well gain wide support. Let us bear in mind the vote of the people of New South Wales on that subject. If we were to join that concept of simultaneous elections, as indeed is proposed in Senator Evans's Bill, with senators' terms consisting of two House of Representatives terms, we might have the basis for a realistic solution. Although the simultaneous elections proposal in 1977 failed to attract support from a majority of States it was endorsed by over 62 per cent of the popular vote at that referendum. Such a solution would, I believe, preserve the co- ordinate and co-equal status of the Senate.

Let us bear in mind that a poll taken as late as December 1981 indicated that about 51 per cent of Australians believed present Senate powers to be about right, 17 per cent believed they were not great enough and only 16 per cent believed that they were too great. On the other hand, the Senate knows that in exercising its powers at least half of the Senate would have to face the electorate. Under the Court proposal, of course, the whole of the Senate would have to face the electorate. I realise that some senators do not support the simultaneous elections proposal. However, it may be the only acceptable way of accommodating the four-year term proposal to our bicameral system. It would offer significant advantages in its own right. As well as reducing the number of elections it would, by ensuring that the peoples' will is reflected simultaneously in both Houses, provide a more satisfactory electoral basis on which the government of the day could proceed. However, the Government will not support a proposal to strip the Senate of its powers and to prevent governments from accounting to, or appealing to, the electorate. For all these reasons, it will not support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some degree of disappointment that I follow the response of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to the proposal before this chamber and, indeed, before the Parliament. It is surprising, surely , that the Attorney could find nothing good in the proposal. He characterised it as being a proposal of mere expediency. It is true that it is expedient that we, as a Senate, as a Parliament, deal with the unresolved dilemma left to us by the framers of the Constitution who created a political structure where the Executive is simultaneously responsible to two chambers, each of which can be constituted by different groups and alliances so that quite different political movements may have a majority in each of the chambers. It is expedient that we deal with that matter. But that is not to say that it cannot be dealt with in a principled way. I believe that the proposal put forward by Senator Evans can be called, if one likes, a principled expedient. It seems that there ought to be common ground between us that the traumatic events of 1975 ought not occur again . As the Canberra Times of 11 November 1981 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an event which at the time benefited conservatives is now generally recognised as one which has endangered both conservatives and radicals. It has made good government, by either side, impossible.
That point needs to be kept in mind as we seek a spirit which would govern this sort of discussion.

The nature of the proposal is well known and fairly easily summarised, at least as to the core of it. It is that there should be fixed parliamentary terms with elections for both the House or Representatives and the Senate to be held every third Saturday of every third November. This would give a government security of tenure, generally speaking, against a hostile Senate. At the same time as a trade-off, the Government would lose its present prerogative of calling an early election to suit its political advantage. There are two necessary exceptions to this rule. One allows for an election if a government is defeated in the House of Representatives on a formal vote of no confidence and if no alternative Ministry emerges within seven days. The other provides for a double dissolution at the Government's discretion to break a sustained deadlock between the Houses on a series of legislative measures other than those money Bills critical to a government's continuing capacity to govern.

I believe that the core of the proposal for a fixed term parliament is based, in the widespread community sense, on the fact that Australians are subjected to too many elections or, at least, to too many unpredictable elections which are called so often to secure some transient political advantage or to secure, on the basis of some temporary political support, yet another term in office. On 11 November last year, again concerning the constancy of elections to which the Australian people are subjected, the editor of the Australian Financial Review stated:

It is all very well to say that ''the people should decide,'' but the people sometimes get very tired of having to go through tedious election campaigns which are out of context and aimed primarily at solving problems which their elected repesentatives are unable to solve for themselves.
An excessive number of elections is a serious impediment to the effecitve functioning of democratic government-paradoxical as thay may at first seem.

I believe that if the people become confused, bewildered and then apathetic about the manipulation of the political process, the dangers foreseen by the editorial writer of the Australian of 13 November 1981 will come to pass. The editorial writer stated:
It is essential for a democracy that the average interested citizen should know how the system works.

At the moment, without the fixed term, the average person in a democracy has no real conception of what political electoral processes he is to be subjected to at the whim of the Prime Minister. The editorial continues:

If people cannot understand the rules of the game it is not to be wondered at if some of them wish to abandon the game altogether and try to attain their political goals by other, unconstitutional, means.

There can be no doubt that Australia is governed less well than it would be were it the case that we had a more stable, assured term of office guaranteed to the government of the day, whatever its political complex. Let us not forget that the Australian national Government is based on compulsory universal franchise. To my mind, that invests it with a true democratic authority which is lacking even in some comparable Western democracies, like the United States, which do have a fixed term but which do not have compulsory franchise. In fact, President Reagan is in office with a mere 26 per cent of the vote-51 per cent of some 51 per cent of people who decided to vote. But the Australian Government is invested invariably with a much more solid vote of those entitled to vote in a federal election. It is invested with a true democratic authority. In my view it ought to be allowed to run, indeed it ought to be required to run, its full term . This would give a stability within which brave decision-making could be undertaken by a government without the constant apprehension that it would be politically unfortunate for it to undertake a particular course of action, say, after the mid-term point has been reached in its, at the moment, unfixed term of office. The Australian Financial Review, not the most radical journal in Australia, on 11 November 1981 stated:
The point is the effectiveness and consistency of the constitutional framework which now supports the right of an elected government to conduct its business.

If Australian parliamentary terms ran for five years as those in the United Kingdom do, there might well be the strong arguments for having a Senate capable of exercising restraint on the Government of the day.

But three-year terms barely give the elected Government time to introduce any unpopular policies-some of which are always essential if it is to do its job- before it has to consider its electoral stance for the coming poll.
The short term of the Australian Parliament is itself a watchdog factor-an influence for keeping the bastards honest.

That is said with due deference to the Australian Democrats. That is what the editorial writer said. Those words would never fall from my lips voluntarily. The fact is that we are not arguing for a four-year term; we are arguing for a fixed three-year term. That in itself brings certain restraints and limitations to bear on what a government will attempt to do during that term.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not both-fixed terms and four years?

—Because it is important, I believe, that honourable senators enjoy two concurrent House of Representatives measured terms. To ask the electorate to endorse their elected representatives in this place for some eight years would be, I believe, to ask too much of the democratic process. I think six years in this chamber is enough. To return to the point of the need for stability and the need for a government to be sure of its term in order to make the sorts of hard decisions that might be made, I need do no more than refer to the Australian of the 13 November 1981, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Neither a Reagan nor a Mitterrand could carry out their policies if they were faced with the situation which faced Mr Whitlam and now faces Mr Fraser. In our present crisis consistent economic policies are more necessary than ever. Under our Constitution no Government can follow consistent policies if it does not have the numbers in the Senate.
For these reasons, and to avoid a harrowing replay of events of 1975, the Government should carefully consider joining the ALP in trying to limit the Senate's financial powers.
These are words from an editorial writer of the Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the Tribune, is it?

—No, it is a very conservative journal within our community. I have quoted extensively and perhaps tediously from the Australian Financial Review and from the Australian to indicate to the Senate how far from being in touch with reality the Attorney-General is in his response tonight, speaking of the proposal from this side of the chamber as being marked by mere expediency. It is expedient that we deal with the problem but I believe we have attempted to approach the matter in a principled way, and that is recognised by the sorts of journals to which I have referred.
—Do you think he is like the Bourbons of old?
—Learn nothing and remember nothing.

—Learn nothing and remember nothing; that is correct. I believe in this Bill, with the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Evans last Thursday night , there is a foundation for constitutional reform which is based in the common sense of the people who do not want to be subjected to the uncertainty of elections called at the whim of a Prime Minister and, indeed, on the common experience of government in its need for a stability within which to pursue the policies for which it has a mandate. Therefore, I believe that the proposal from this side of the chamber is an altogether more comprehensive basis and gives us a more comprehensive context within which to seek a meeting between the major parties before going to the people with a referendum proposal. A bipartisan attitude would be essential to any referendum success. This is reflected in the Age of 11 November. This is my last quotation from the editorial response to the proposal as first put forward late last year. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a genuine, realistic attempt to resolve irreconcilable and troublesome concepts embedded in the Constitution, and it deserves consideration on its merits beyond immediate partisan and parochial interest.

I hope that this chamber can give the proposal that sort of consideration. The Labor Party has sought to go beyond its initial vigorous response to the events of 1975. Honourable senators will recall that at that time our response was to say that the Senate should lose all power to reject or block money Bills of whatever description. The sole beneficiary of that sort of constitutional reform could only be the government of the day. The Bill also supersedes Sir Charles Court's proposal, which found some acceptance by a bare majority of the Constitutional Convention in Perth, that an automatic double dissolution should follow the failure to pass the Appropriation Bills. The sole beneficiary of that proposal would be the Senate and, to an extent also, the office of Governor- General in that it would have removed from it its present discretionary powers. We say that some solution is needed to the problems of the 1975 money Bills, to speak of them generally, and that our latest proposal-the proposal put to the chamber for consideration-would benefit the Government to the extent that we now say that a hostile Senate could not block those measures necessary to secure a government's capacity to govern, whether that be on the revenue raising or appropriating side.

The Bills circulated in November spoke of the Senate's concurrence not being required for the passage of any taxation or appropriation measure. I want it clearly noted that, after consultation on this side of the chamber, there has been a move to the position where we now propose that the Senate ought not to block those measures which are necessary to secure a government's capacity to govern. We refer there to both revenue raising and appropriation measures. That is obviously a much narrower category of money Bills than was formerly spoken of . It ought not to be forgotten that even with this proposal it is not said that the Senate should never see such Bills or consider such Bills. The concurrence of the Senate will always be sought in the months or 30 days that are allowed for. Full deliberation and debate would occur on those crucial, critical money Bills and, no doubt, requests during that time could be transmitted to the House of Representatives for its consideration.

Those are the parameters and the extent of the role which the proposal allows the Senate in relation to these crucial money Bills. This particular distinction has arisen, I take it, out of our experience in this chamber in very recent times. It is said that a distinction can be drawn between, on the one hand, revenue raising measures or Bills earmarking moneys or revenue for government programs or administration generally which are essential to the survival of the Government or its capacity to govern and, on the other hand, those Bills which are arguably not so radically essential to the continuance of government but which, however, might impair particular programs, whatever their impact on general government revenues. One has in mind the Medibank levy rejected by the Opposition in this chamber during the Labor Government's time or the sales tax levy on certain items rejected by the Opposition in this chamber in recent weeks .

I have claimed that there is such a distinction, that arguably this distinction can be drawn. I confess to some discomforture with the distinction. Whilst it is clear at the extremes where certain money Bills might lie-for example, there is a clear difference between the Supply Bills and a Bill appropriating several hundred thousand dollars for an agricultural research fund-it would be a brave person who could argue with absolute certainty about all the types of measures of a money character which might come into this chamber.

The fact that a government might not crumble in a fiscal sense on the rejection of the Medibank levy proposal or the sales tax on the essentials of life proposal is in itself no real indication of either the centrality of the measure to its electorally mandated program, as in the case of the Medibank levy, or the centrality betokened by the sales tax measures that we rejected. That measure really did betoken a fundamental shift of government revenue raising policy of profound significance. The fact is that governments prefer to govern and they will find other ways of funding a program or raising revenue if it is at all possible.

I believe the Committee stage will give us sufficient opportunity to seek wording which could embody the distinction. That is the role of this chamber at the Committee stage. The point I am trying to make is that this particular refinement, this difficult distinction that we are trying to draw is, in fact, a demonstration of the willingness of honourable senators on this side of the chamber to go beyond the proposal of last November. I believe that we have thereby signalled that we are prepared to move very significantly to accommodate to the greatest extent possible, consistent with our principles, those who objected to the proposal last November that the Senate should lose power over all money Bills of whatever description.

I will return to the fixed term concept. As I said, the government of the day would be disadvantaged by such a proposal to the extent that it could not go to the people part way through its term hoping to avoid certain defeat at the end of the term. To put it more positively, as Senator Lewis and Senator Durack have tried to do, the government may seek a mandate on a crucial matter which, although not the substance of legislation rejected by the Senate, it needs to address but would prefer to do so with full expressed community support. That sort of power of the Government is hereby lost should this proposal be commended by the people. Of course-I cannot emphasise this too much-the Senate is still well able under our proposal to reject or to fail to pass legislative measures which a government might well regard as critical to its program.

The Senate still retains a tremendous range of law-making power under this proposal. As I said, measures which are quite critical to a government's mandated program could well be rejected by the Senate under this proposal. One has in mind such matters as legislation in the field of industrial relations or the national government's role in off-shore areas beyond the low water mark. If the frustration of a program of the government was intense enough, radically impairing the governing of the country according to the Executive's wishes, then a double dissolution could be called by the Government to resolve the deadlock which the Senate had created by the excise of its co-equal legislative powers. It is wrong to suggest that this proposal strips away the deliberative legislative law-making functions of this chamber. It does so in relation to a special category of money Bills-those which are crucial to a government's capacity to govern, whether concerning revenue raising or the earmarking of moneys for expenditure.

In this proposal there is no question of the Senate losing its general law- making power. If the Government's policy is frustrated intensely enough or radically enough or over a wide range of measures then indeed it could call for a double dissolution to resolve the deadlock under the proposal now before the chamber. That was foreshadowed last Thursday night by my colleague, Senator Evans, as shadow Attorney-General. In the Bill circulated last November such a deadlock might have been resolved in one of two ways, either by double dissolution or by a joint sitting of the Parliament. That joint sitting would have had certain safeguards built into it so that not only would an absolute majority of the total number of the members of the two Houses be required to determine a question but also, in the case of each of at least one-half of the States, the proposal would need to be affirmed by at least one-half of the total number of the members of the two Houses chosen in or for the State.

That was a rather difficult clause to draft but it was meant to embody some of the Federal characteristics which are lost when the bicameral legislature resolves into one chamber as it would at a joint sitting. Naturally, that clause was put in to try to allay the fears of those who would see in the joint sitting proposal too automatic a carrying into effect of the House of Representatives' will in regard to a particular legislative measure. On reflection it has been decided to abandon that clause and this proposal so that the only way of resolving a deadlock between two chambers is go to the people in a double dissolution. In that respect, as I said, we have abandoned a proposal which had merit and which in fact was endorsed and put forward by the 1959 Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. In our desire to see a proposal come to this chamber which could command as wide a degree of support as possible we have said the only way to resolve the deadlock should be by double dissolution and fresh elections for both chambers. Further, whereas in the original proposal in November it was the case that following a double dissolution called by a government-its program being imperilled by the Senate-the new Parliament constituted after the election would commence a new fixed term, we say now that the new Parliament should merely see out the remainder of the fixed term during the course of which the double dissolution has been called.

Of course, the proposal now means that if a double dissolution is called 18 months into a fixed term the new House of Representatives will see out only the remaining 18 months. Once again, this is a most important concession. It is a concession to those who argued, I think with a degree of justice, that the original proposal was overly advantageous, and therefore tempting, to a government which might contrive a double dissolution two years into its fixed term knowing that the final year of its fixed term might be extremely difficult- for example, in controlling the economy. I instance a foreshadowed decline in international trade. It would be very advantageous and tempting under the original proposal for a government to create a double dissolution in order to get a new three-year fixed term. Our amended proposal does away with that possibility.

It is interesting to note that in the Attorney's recalling of an incident in the West German political system he failed to say whether Willy Brandt thereby obtained a completely fresh fixed term or merely saw out the original fixed term . If it was the former, then indeed in our proposal before the chamber tonight we have met that objection.

In three crucial respects, since the Bill was circulated last November, the Labor Party has sought to create a situation in which this chamber can endorse a Bill for a referendum to go to the people. I think this needs to be emphasised. We are not here making law. We are not here involved ourselves in changing the Constitution. We are trying to settle on a scheme which, by enhancing our democratic processes, can be commended to the people by all major political groupings. But ultimately we are putting to the people a proposal. Therefore, I think it is right that we should not be too wedded to our partisan political views. We need to create a situation in which the people can be presented with a proposal which has a reasonable chance of passage.

As I said, I was extremely disappointed by the Attorney-General's response in that he found nothing good whatsoever in the Bill. It has five or six major elements, as Senator Lewis, who has now entered the chamber, pointed out in his speech last Thursday night. Some of them have more attraction than others. I will mention two which I found most attractive. The first is-the core of the matter as I see it-that the government of the day, if the proposal is carried, should be that group of Australians who enjoy the confidence of a majority of the House of Representatives. The Government should be destroyed only by losing that confidence or should be tested in the electorate only by the deliberate will of the House of Representatives in seeking to resolve a deadlock with the Senate. I find that proposal extremely appealing. The Bill expressly articulates what used to be a convention before 1975 and relieves the Governor-General of his decision-making role which he assumed in 1975 and which even the most reactionary members of our community now agree he should not be called upon to exercise. They do so because they feel that there is a risk of the Governor- General's so impairing the reputation of the office that it would be quite definitely imperilled. There is no doubt that any repetition of the event of 1975 and the Governor-General's involvement in it would lead to such a political upheaval that the office would not survive.

I think it is important for many reasons that the office of the Governor- General does survive. There are those within the community who see the office of Governor-General as providing a valued link with the Crown and all the traditions which came to this country as a result of the rule of law and democratic procedures derived from the British Isles. I do not share that view. As the Senate would know, I believe that we should cut the nexus between Australia and the Crown. Nevertheless I believe the Governor-General has an important role in an Australian republic. I can see a transition to a republic where the Governor-General no longer has a constitutional role as representing the Crown, but, in fact, fulfils all the functions presently vested in him as the symbolic and, indeed, useful apex of our system of Government. However the Governor-General must exercise no discretion which would enable him to do as the then Governor-General did in 1975, that is select the Leader of the Opposition as the Prime Minister of the day. The House of Representatives must be, as this Bill proposes, the body properly constituted to create the Government of the day . the Prime Minister should be the person who commands its confidence and should resign if that confidence is lost, but only in that situation.

A further aspect of the Bill which commends itself to me is the concurrence of the terms of House of Represenatives members with those of senators, senators holding office for two House of Representatives terms. At the moment there is an absolutely absurd and undemocratic situation prevailing. I was elected in late 1977 and Senator Chipp was elected in late 1980. Although we were elected in those years we in fact did not take our places in the chamber until the July following, some seven or eight months after our election. Those honourable senators who either did not contest the election because they were retiring from the Senate or who were voted out by the people were still in this chamber for those eight months engaging in the deliberate law-making process of this nation while we who had been elected were out in the wilderness. Concurrence of terms is a most important advance.

I gave an undertaking to the Whip that I would speak only for 30 minutes. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I reiterate that we are not changing the Constitution; we are concerned to devise a proposal which will allow the Australian people to make their choice as to a change in the Constitution. It is a conservative electorate; it is a very peculiarly constructed electorate for the purpose of constitutional change. I believe that this proposal has enough merit in it to receive a second reading from this chamber. At the Committee stage we can refine it as may be necessary so that ultimately a proposal to overcome the traumatic events of 1975 can go to the people.
