SPEECH.PARA: Motion for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 274 and made under the Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act 1977 be disallowed.

I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Perhaps I should make it clear that I am not speaking on behalf of the Committee because, as Senator Lewis indicated, the Committee decided not to proceed with the disallowance motion. I do not want to go too deeply into the whole contents of this matter. However, it really started in about 1979 when the Government indicated that it was proposing to introduce streamlining procedures relating to promotions and appeals in the Public Service. A lot of events have happened since then in related fields, such as the Ellicott judgment in the Finch case. These regulations were introduced on 27 September 1981. The notice of intention to disallow was given by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee Chairman on 24 November 1981. On 11 March-that is only within the last fortnight-the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) replied to the Committee. The matter relates to the giving of reasons in connection with Public Service promotions and promotion appeals.

The problem is that the regulations take away rights of individuals. They were initially taken away for 12 months by an Act of this Parliament, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The regulations introduced last year sought to extend that removal of rights for a further 12 months. The extension brings about an undue restriction on people for yet another 12 months. It may be argued that there are only six months of that period left in which to proceed. On 29 October last year the Government introduced the Public Service Act Amendment Bill into the House of Representatives. It has sat somewhere near the bottom of the Notice Paper since then. Of course, one of the problems with this whole matter is timing. This is the fifteenth sitting day, the last possible day for this matter to be dealt with. It was today that the Government agreed to the Committee's proposal that it would advance the consideration of the Public Service Amendment Bill in the House of Representatives. I disagreed with that decision of the Committee to accept that arrangement as a reason for not proceeding with the disallowance.

The problem is that this whole matter of promising to bring on the Bill does not remove or minimise the present problem of a lack of rights to reasons. It has to be said that the Government will not necessarily propose amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act which are acceptable to all concerned, whether it be the intent of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in attempting to co-operate with the Government, or the Public Service unions involved, or anybody else for that matter. It has been going on for some years now. I think we should indicate to the Government that it is time that the Government and the Public Service Board provided the framework for the giving of reasons. I believe that that is sufficient argument to support the proposition that the regulations be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the motion for disallowance of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Regulations. I am pleased that the correspondence that I have had with the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been tabled. I hope that honourable senators will have the opportunity of reading that correspondence before they vote on this motion. By and large, public servants, along with the rest of the community, have not had the right at any stage to receive reasons for administrative decisions. There may be some situations where a right was created. Under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act there is a right of appeal to obtain a reason for a decision by the Tribunal . Until the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act was proclaimed on 1 October 1980 there was no general right for anybody, including public servants, to obtain reasons for promotion and transfer decisions. Of course, when the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act was proclaimed this was one of the great advances in the civil rights of Australians. However, that Act provided for an exemption for 12 months for decisions relating to promotions and transfers of public servants. That exemption was recommended by the Administrative Review Council to enable the Public Service Board to get its procedures into shape to cope with the need to give reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service Board has been concerned with this and many other problems, particularly the implementation of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, chaired by Dr Coombs. Unfortunately it was not in a position to put before the Parliament a major Bill concerning not only this question but also many other major questions affecting the Public Service within the time frame allowed by the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The period of grace of 12 months which was provided in the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act expired on 30 September last year before the legislation that the Public Service Board and the Government, on its recommendation, proposed to put before the Parliament was in place. That is a matter of regret and--

TALK.START.PARA: —And staff shortages.

—Not only staff shortages but also a lot of other major issues were involved in it. All that I can do is express regret. But that is the situation. The new code relating to public servants which dealt with many problems, in particular the problem we have before us tonight, was not available on that date. Accordingly, the Government decided that it would take advantage of an opportunity to promulgate regulations which would extend for one further year the exemption of the Public Service Board from providing reasons in these cases, to enable this legislation to be brought before the Parliament and for the whole question to be determined by the Parliament. Senator Coates said that somehow or other these regulations are taking away rights that people have. That is not the fact. Public servants do not have and never have had the right to obtain reasons for decisions relating to promotion or transfer. The Government and the Public Service Board recognises-I think it is widely accepted-that these people ought to have some rights in this regard. The major part of the Public Service Amendment Bill has already been introduced but correspondence which has been tabled indicates that the Government has drafted and is about to introduce amendments to that legislation which will provide a method of giving to an unsuccessful applicant reasons why he was not successful in his promotion appeal .

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty that we face with the blanket application of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act is that, in giving reasons in a very broad sense under that Act why a particular applicant did not succeed, one would have to provide all sorts of information about all the other unsuccessful applicants. Questions of confidentiality are very deeply involved. I have no reason to believe that the proposed statement of reasons which will be provided for in this legislation to be proposed to the Parliament will not be satisfactory as far as this aspect of it is concerned.

In anticipation of a full debate on this subject in this Parliament over forthcoming weeks the Government is concerned that the whole question of giving reasons should be immediately thrown completely into the melting pot by vote of the Senate tonight. If this motion succeeds-perhaps in many respects this is because procedures are not available and have not been developed-the full effect of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act will come into force tomorrow. But those provisions will be in force only until the Parliament determines in the next few weeks the nature of the reasons to be given to public servants in respect of promotion and transfer decisions. I find it very difficult to understand the purpose of the Senate disallowing these regulations tonight. They really only preserve the status quo until the Parliament deals with this matter. I might say, in addition to what I said in the letter-perhaps this should have been included in it-that the Bill will have provisions for the new procedures to be brought into effect as soon as possible after assent is given to that legislation. It will not be a matter of waiting until 30 September this year before the provision takes effect. It can take effect virtually as soon as assent to the Bill has been given.

The effect of passing this disallowance motion tonight will be simply to bring in some quite new form of reasons which no one has ever had before, which are not really applicable to the Public Service and which will be effective only until the Parliament, in the forthcoming weeks, determines its attitude on this measure. The Parliament will not necessarily accept the proposals contained in the Bill, but it will have the fullest opportunity to determine what it believes should be the right procedures. All I am saying is that I hope the Senate will not take action tonight which will anticipate in many ways the decisions of this Parliament and which at best will have the effect only of implementing a system which may well be changed by this Parliament in the course of the next few weeks . I want to stress again that there is no question that these regulations, which the motion seeks to disallow, are in fact removing any rights that public servants now have. They have never had those rights.

It may be a matter of regret that they have never had them. I could not agree more; I have been a great proponent of the reasons for decision principle and I thoroughly support the notion that there should be reasons available. It is a question only in regard to promotions and transfer decisions as to what is the appropriate form of those reasons. As I said, that is the matter which will be dealt with in the legislation which Parliament will have the fullest opportunity of debating and determining in the remaining weeks of the current session.

I hope the Senate will not support this motion to disallow which seems to have been moved by some misapprehension as to the actual state of the law at the moment. This is ahead of and in anticipation of the major consideration of this whole matter which will be before the Senate in the next few weeks. As I said, whatever decision the Parliament comes to on this measure will be given immediate effect by the terms of the Bill and by the undertaking which I am giving to the Parliament on behalf of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this discussion for a couple of minutes to query the whole basis of the reply by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). He said that the Senate should maintain the status quo created by the present regulation as though that were desired. But the fact is that the status quo desired by this Parliament, when it passed section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, was that a person aggrieved by a decision ought to be able to obtain the reasons for that decision. That is the right which this Parliament-the House of Representatives and the Senate-agreed ought to be conferred on or ought to inhere in a person aggrieved by a decision, including a decision as to promotion or transfer within the Public Service. In fact this Parliament decided that that right ought to exist, or it decided, if one likes, to recognise that right within a public servant aggrieved by a decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulation therefore alters the status quo-the prevailing situation-desired by the elected representatives of the people. The Executive decided that that situation should not prevail initially for a period of 12 months. When this initial 12-month period was decided upon as a breather in order to get procedures streamlined and in accordance with the general desire that reasons be provided, the unions agreed. The Administrative and Clerical Officers Association agreed that that ought to be the case. The unions in this respect are, of course, entirely reasonable. It would have been unreasonable of them to expect that these procedures could suddenly be brought into operation overnight. But now the Executive is saying to this Parliament: 'We want to frustrate the will of the Parliament as expressed in the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act for yet another 12 months.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit rough.
—You did not listen to what I said.

—That is how I read it and that is what I believe is occurring. This time it has been done without any consultation with the unions. This further extension of 12 months was announced to the unions at the very same time as the heads of department were informed by the Public Service Board that this was the case. The Public Service Board-the Government, if one likes-has become undone by its own failure to move expeditiously in a manner in which it knew it had to move because it knew as well as anyone that the Senate would be engaged in the sort of discussion in which it is engaged tonight. For the Senate to disallow this regulation would be indeed to allow the right to operate which this Parliament desired should operate. It might do so only for a period of weeks. It might be that when the Parliament is presented with the Public Service Act amendments we will find that the procedures set down with the various methods of giving reasons and so on are adequate. It may be that we do not find them adequate and that amendments are proposed in this chamber on representation by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the ACOA or indeed out of our own good sense, in which case the matter might not be resolved until the Budget session. There is certainly no guarantee that the amendment to the Public Service Act will be passed during the autumn session which, as we know, will be truncated and could well be over, as far as this chamber is concerned, by 6 May.

SPEECH.PARA: What we on this side of the chamber are saying-I believe that the sentiment is shared by others on this side of the chamber outside the Australian Labor Party- is that in the interim before the Parliament comes to a decision in relation to the amendment to the Public Service Act that has been foreshadowed the rights which this Parliament has desired should be exercised by public servants, as by all others aggrieved by these sorts of decisions, ought to be exercised. It is my understanding in any case that the various promotion appeal tribunals are geared up to institute a system of giving reasons. I do not believe that any great hardship would be caused to the Public Service in requiring that those reasons be given as from tomorrow. That was the desire of this Parliament. It was agreed that the right ought to be suspended, as it were, for some 12 months. There is now an attempt by the Executive to extend it, without consultation with the unions concerned. I believe that the Parliament should say that the Public Service Board has had time enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I do not agree entirely with the reasons given by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) I am certainly of the view that we should not vote to disallow the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Regulations. I make my appeal to those who are not on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, particularly to the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. There are good reasons why the recommendations of the Committee, which has accepted an undertaking from the Government to do its best to get this legislation dealt with in the session, should be upheld.
—Some members of it.

—I was not at the meeting this evening because of other engagements, as the honourable senator knows, but I certainly would have supported the view which apparently the majority of the Committee then expressed . It seems to me that a good reason has to be found why the Senate should on the motion of a member of the Committee, take a different course, disallow the regulations and create rights which may exist for a few weeks or months before the Parliament has the opportunity of determining, by decisions it makes on the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, what shall be the rights of public servants in this regard. I believe it should not alter rights in this way. As honourable senators know, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee requested advice from the Government on when the Bill would be dealt with. The Bill was introduced to give the opportunity to the public to look at it and express its views late last year. I was very strongly of the view that should be done. I have not heard any comments to indicate any logical views on the Bill. I hope that there will be.
—But the relevant amendments have still to be introduced.
—There are further amendments to come, and I am very interested to hear that tonight. I will be very interested to see those amendments and I will reserve judgment on them until I have seen them.
—So will the general public. That is why you haven't got any letters.

—The general public will also want to see the Attorney's amendments, make up its mind about them and make further representations. But there has been very little representation on the Bill, which was introduced in November. Mr Paul Munro, the National Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, sent a telegram in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the latter Bill-that is, the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill- the ACTU asked the Public Service Board and the Government in October to set aside certain parts of the Bill for further consultation through joint council. It is my understanding that that request of the ACTU has not been acceded to by the Government.

In fact, the whole Bill has been before the public since November. We have been awaiting, as members of parliament, the views of the Public Service unions and the public. I would be very interested to know the views of public servants in regard to the rights that ought to be enjoyed by them in promotions and appeals. It is not just a matter of what the Government might discuss with the joint councils; the public and other members of parliament ought to know the views of public servants on this matter. A delay has occurred over the last few months so that the public can have the opportunity of coming forward with those ideas. Now that the question of disallowance is to be considered the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has given notice that it will hold its position because there is a certain connection between the regulations and the proposed Bill. We have had an undertaking from the Attorney in his letter of 23 March 1982. Although the letter has been tabled I think it is important that I should read a paragraph. He said:

I am now writing to assure you that it is the intention of the Government to bring forward these amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, including the proposed amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, to be moved in the House of Representatives and to seek to have the Bill taken through all stages in the House of Representatives and brought forward for debate in the Senate during the present period of Sittings, and that the Government will use its best endeavours to give effect to this intention.

That is a very clear and desirable undertaking. It is important that the decision should be not made upon the termination of a regulation to create rights which, as the Attorney has said, did not exist in the past and which may last for a period of only a few months. The decision should be made following debate in this chamber and in the House of Representatives on the amending Bill.

I have certain reservations about the terms of the original Bill relating to this subject. It deals with a number of other matters as well which I make no comment upon. I probably diverge somewhat from the Attorney's view but Mr Justice Ellicott found in the Goldstein case that public servants have, on appeals and promotions, rights of natural justice and rights to hear the other side and to know the case against them, and my understanding is that the Bill is designed to change the results of that judgment. In other words, it will take away some of the rights of public servants at common law. That proposal must be scrutinised very carefully by the Parliament before it happens. I can well see that where many people are seeking promotion there are practical difficulties in regard to making available details of everyone else's qualifications and applications. A question of privacy may be concerned but it is important that people have a right to know the cases they have to answer and to know the types of qualifications held by those who are competing for the same jobs so that they can put their cases properly. There are rights which must be carefully scrutinised when this Bill comes before this chamber for consideration. But we should not determine tonight to disallow a regulation which extends the period of 12 months in the original Act.

Senator Tate said that it was intended by the Parliament that the period should be only 12 months and then the rights should proceed. I think we would all regret that the change in the law was not dealt with within that 12 months period and that, for whatever reason, the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill was not dealt with in that time. But it was not. To suggest that the Parliament consciously formed a conclusion that it would want an extension of only 12 months and would not want any further extension is quite unjustifiable. In view of the importance of the Bill it would be ridiculous, I suggest, for this chamber to disallow a regulation, create some rights which would give people an impression that that would be the permanent situation and then perhaps take those rights away in three or four months or change them in some way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three or four months? How long are you going to extend this?
—I think we would consider this as a 12 months' further extension . I cannot imagine voting for a further extension. There is a Bill already before the Parliament.
—There cannot be a further extension.
—I am assured by the Attorney that there cannot be a further extension. Probably because of the terms of the Act there is no power to extend further the time.
—Parliament gave the power.

—As the Attorney points out, Parliament gave the Government the power to extend it further. There is nothing extraordinary about that and that was the intention of the Parliament when it passed the Act. We may not have desired that but it was the major will of the Parliament in passing the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The Government has exercised that power with a further extension of 12 months. I suggest that it would be highly desirable if the regulation could stand and that it would be irresponsible to disallow it at this stage. It would also run in the face of undertakings which the Regulations and Ordinance Committee has obtained in good faith from the Government with regard to this Bill. I urge those honourable senators who are not on the cross benches to consider the matter carefully and not vote for disallowance of this regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The item before the Senate tonight is Statutory Rule No. 274 of 1981 in which the Government seeks to extend the period of exclusion of promotion appeals matters from reference to the administrative appeals judicial review process for a further 12 months, as I understand it, from September 1982. This seems to indicate that there is still some time in which progress may be made in relation to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill which has already been the subject of debate tonight. As we see it, the legislation that comes before this chamber from the Government presumably is under Government control. The Government, in terms of its time and that of its departments, can bring forward that legislation when it is prepared. I believe that the Senate must address itself to the issues that are before it. The issue before it at present is the disallowance of Statutory Rule No. 274 of 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that surely is a matter which arises under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. It should, therefore, be dealt with as a matter distinct from the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill when it comes forward. Certainly those pieces of legislation deal with similiar matters, but it does not seem to be appropriate to seek a trade-off between them in terms of whether this statutory rule ought to continue for another 12 months. The onus for the argument for the addition of 12 months must surely lie with the Government. The Parliament allowed a 12-month period. The Government is now seeking an additional 12-month period. The Parliament presumably, if it had sufficient reasons before it, would agree to that. I do not think those reasons have yet been presented.

The discussions in relation to the Public Service Acts do not seem to me to bear terribly strongly upon the matter at all. I presume that as the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill-unlike Senator Missen I have had a great deal of correspondence with relevant organisations already in relation to this Bill- comes closer to debate in this chamber there will be a lot more correspondence and concern within the community on a range of matters in that Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that they will spread it to other senators.
—I invite them to do so.
—Send him some of yours.

—Senator Lewis was complaining that he did not get some a little while ago. Perhaps I could send him some as well. The Public Service Acts Amendment Bill will, I am quite sure, raise many interesting problems. I hope that it will be the basis of considerable debate in this House. This Parliament has a unique responsibility in terms of the Public Service. Surely it must not be under any pressure to move through these Public Service Acts because of the problems in relation to appeals. It would seem to us, therefore, that it would be advisable to allow the disallowance to take place, to allow that right to public servants under the Administrative Appeals (Judicial Review) Act. I accept the point of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that this would mean, indeed, giving public servants a right which they did not have before but it is a right which I believe this Parliament and, indeed, the community in general believe should be there from all judicial acts of government. We are not doing anything terribly radical by extending that right to the Public Service. I believe that when we get around-I say that correctly-to discussing the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, indeed, there are many other matters which are just about to come into the Parliament which do not seem to have arrived here yet, this Parliament will make up its mind in relation to that Bill. I do not think that matter ought to be brought in when discussing this case. We have to address ourselves to this matter. In this matter it seems relatively clear that the Act ought to extend to the Public Service. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will be voting for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Tate clarified the situation for the Senate. The Administrative Appeals (Judicial Review) Act was passed by the Senate and by the House of Representatives. There was an Executive decision to put into place statutory rules which provided exemptions to provisions of the Administrative Appeals (Judicial Review) Act. It was not the decision of the Senate; the decision was taken by the Executive Government after discussions, of course, with relevant organisations so as to allow time for the Public Service Board and others to get their act together. A further decision has been taken by the Executive Government to put in place a statutory rule which would extend that exemption to 31 August of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Senate are being asked to countenance what I believe we should not be asked to countenance; that is, the failure of the relevant authorities to act in accordance with the provisions of the legislation that was passed by the Parliament. It is all very well for the Executive Government-that is its job-to suggest subordinate legislation which would give time, for example, for an organisation under its purview to develop administrative machinery which would be required to ensure the proper operation of legislation. That is fair enough. To suggest that that legislation ought to be extended for another 12 months and to suggest that we in the Senate ought to cop that is not a proper suggestion. I do not blame the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) because it is not his department that is concerned in this case. I have some quarrel with him in respect of a piece of legislation from his Department that will be debated tomorrow. I will have enough arguments with the Attorney-General tomorrow about that piece of legislation relating to family law. However, I am not prepared as a member of this Parliament to allow a situation to continue whereby we give an extended period for a Public Service body, such as the Public Service Board, or other institutions, to develop their machinery which ought to have been developed well and truly before this.

The other aspect I am concerned about is that we have been told by the Attorney -General that of course there will be amendments to the Public Service Acts. Those amendments will bear upon this issue as to the provision of reasons in respect of motions, appeals, and so on. We have the Attorney's assurance that that will be expedited, so far as the Government is concerned, through the House of Representatives and through the Senate. On the other hand, we have heard Senator Missen indicate that, no matter what happens, this statutory rule will expire on 31 August 1982. That is true. If somehow or other the Senate could be assured that the amendments to the Public Service Acts would be dealt with in this session then that would be another question. I cannot see how the Minister can give that assurance because it is really not in his hands. It is in the hands of the Parliament once it hits the deck in the House of Representatives. Of course, it is in our hands when it is dealt with here. I make it perfectly clear that I for one will not be a party to any delay in the amendments to the Public Service Acts. If the Federal Secretary to the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association says that he wants a delay I do not think that is acceptable either. He ought to have his act together and so ought all of the other organisations. I will not be a party-I make that very clear now-to any delay in the passage of appropriate amendments to the Public Service Acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want them to have reasonable time to look at it.

—They have had plenty of time to look at them. Munro has had plenty of time. He ought to have had his act together. That is his trouble; he does not have his act together. I understand the situation very clearly. On this issue I propose to vote-I have expressed my opinion-for the disallowance of this statutory rule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to answer a couple of points made by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and Senator Missen and to emphasise that the rights involved in the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act have already been created. It was the intention of the Parliament that they come into effect about six months ago. The regulation to extend that period certainly was provided, but I would have thought that that was to cover a situation of a few weeks-perhaps an emergency situation-when the matter was in the last throes of being dealt with. Even though this extension has been by way of regulation, it has still had an effect for a further six months. It has not been just an emergency extension; it already has lasted six months. I think that is a very unfortunate part of this whole process and the procedure of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though 15 sitting days can be allowed for notice to be given and then 15 sitting days for the matter to be dealt with, it has taken from September last year until now, the last possible date, for it to be dealt with. This has meant that there has been legislation by regulation for all that time. The Government has taken total advantage of those two lots of 15 sitting days. The time has been stretched to the absolute limit. The Government knew that this notice for disallowance had been given. Apparently it has had very little effect on the Government getting its act together and providing the proper legislation that is required. As I have said before, the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill is before the House of Representatives. To clarify the point that Senator Harradine was making, I inform the Senate that the relevant amendments that we are talking about are not contained in that Bill as it now stands. They are amendments which the Government has yet to introduce as amendments to that Bill. In fact, they have yet to be drafted. The instructions have only just gone to the--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so. The Bill is drafted and ready to be introduced.
—Can the Minister give us an indication as to when?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durak-I cannot tell you, but the Bill is drafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, only in recent days did the instructions go to the draftsmen as to how the amendments ought to be changed. I would suggest to Senator Harradine-I hope in a quite reasonable fashion-that once those amendments hit the deck he would want there to be at least some reasonable time for consultation with the relevant unions. This has not happened properly so far . The other point that needs to be made about the Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act amendments, which apparently are to be part of this package , is that the rights which those amendments will remove from the present Act may be totally unacceptable to the unions involved or to the Parliament in its decision making process or the public generally. It may be that the amendments are not judged to be able to work in a proper fashion. So despite the fact that we may be wanting to give a speedy passage to whatever amendments come through for the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, there is at least a chance that they will not be passed even by September, at which time the regulations will expire anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make the point that it is improper to extend this suspension of rights by using regulations for such a long period-not just for a few days or weeks, but for a period which was set out to be 12 months. Even though extension was made by way of regulations and had the possibility of being disallowed by the Parliament, just by the mere effluxion of time it has been in effect for six months anyway. As Senator Missen said, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances proposed-or the majority of the Committee members proposed-its compromise with the Government in good faith. I do not believe that ought to take away the right to disallow these regulations. We ought to ensure that the rights which were intended to be given to members of the Public Service last year are provided. We ought to ensure that their rights are enhanced so that their apparent faith in the Government can be restored.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coates's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY SUPPLY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Bill establishes procedures for the emergency rationing of electricity in the Australian Capital Territory. Limitations on power supplies have been an ongoing problem in south-eastern Australia in recent years, with the blackouts and restrictions in Victoria in 1979 and 1980 and, more recently, in New South Wales. Since New South Wales supplies 60 per cent of the electricity consumed in the Australian Capital Territory, the remaining 40 per cent coming from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, in the view of the Opposition it is quite sensible for the Government to introduce legislation of this type. The Opposition supports the Bill. After the Bill has been passed, as I expect it will be tonight, the Minister for the Capital Territory may issue guidelines which will become operative within five sitting days of the Parliament. Emergency regulations may be then issued at any time. They would become operative immediately but would be subject to the normal disallowance procedures within 15 sitting days.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the five sitting days required between the issuing of the guidelines and the subsequent issuing of regulations, the legislation could not become effective until very close to the end of April. I presume that by that stage it will have become an Act. Since it was introduced into the House of Representatives on 10 March and there have been five sitting days since 10 March , I think the Government has been probably a little tardy in introducing the Bill into the Senate, given the very serious situation currently existing in and around Canberra. As Senator Jessop said this morning-I think I have his words down correctly-'saving electricity in the Australian Capital Territory could mean saving jobs in New South Wales'. It is probably a pity that this legislation was not introduced into the Senate last week so that it could have been operative by the end of this week. However, I do not want to be too critical on that matter.

There is without doubt great scope for conservation of and reductions in electricity usage in this city and, indeed, in Australia generally without, I might add, imposing significant hardships or even inconvenience on citizens. Australia's usage of electricity is profligate and has been profligate for many years-a profligate usage encouraged ironically to some extent by the very electricity authorities which are now unable to meet the demand which they themselves have helped to generate. I notice that there has been in Parliament House today-I presume this is not coincidental-some attempt to restrict electricity consumption. Many of the lights which are normally on in the corridors have been off. I applaud that move. I would also applaud more rational management of the air conditioning system in this building. In wintertime the normal temperature in this building seems to be too high and in summertime too low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It might vary from one office to another but certainly in the part of the building where my office is that is the impression that I usually get. It certainly would not impose any great physical discomfort on any of us if the temperature were allowed to vary somewhat more than it does to be more attuned to the outside temperatures, with very great savings of current as a result. Of course, while the amount of electricity used in this building is insignificant compared with the total electricity consumption, it is symptomatic of the profligate usage of electricity to which we have become conditioned and which, with or without any problems regarding the supply of electricity in Victoria or New South Wales or anywhere else, could be modified with considerable social advantage. The attempts to economise on electricity usage in this building were not apparently applied last night by other Public Service buildings in Canberra, judging from the photograph on the front page of the Canberra Times this morning which showed many buildings-though I would not say all were public buildings, one was for certain a public building at Russell Hill -fully illuminated in the middle of the night. That is, of course, not uncommon as anyone who moves around Canberra at night will know. The Treasury building, for example, is normally lit as late as 2 a.m. and, for all I know, is lit right through until daylight. That is a matter which has been taken up in Estimates committee meetings in the past.
—They reckon Fraser is turning the lights off instead of on.

—I suppose this Government probably reckons that once the lights have been turned off, it is a lot more difficult to turn them on again than it claimed it was a few years ago. It said that it could turn the lights on in 1975 and it has yet to do it. Perhaps, as Senator McIntosh implies, that is at the root of the previous reluctance to save electricity by switching off superfluous lighting.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a couple of words on the details of the Bill. I understand that some concern has been expressed by residents of the Australian Capital Territory on civil liberties grounds. There appears to be a belief that premises may be subjected to arbitrary search by officials enforcing whatever regulations may be issued. It is explicitly provided in the Bill that a warrant must be issued before officials can search for that reason. It seems that that is adequately covered. The Government has also, in this Bill, taken the opportunity to make other amendments to the principal Act, one of which conforms with the policy adopted by the Government some years ago with respect to the declaration of pecuniary interests by members of statutory authorities of the Commonwealth. The Bill provides that members of authorities must declare their pecuniary interests and that where they have a conflict of interest they shall not take part in relevant deliberations of the authority. It provides for the sacking of members who do not abide by those rules. The Opposition supported the insertion of similar rules into other Acts governing statutory authorities. In this case we welcome it also. It is a pity, perhaps, that the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) declines to apply the same sort of pecuniary interest tests within his own Cabinet that the Government is applying to statutory authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer the some aspects of the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Bill 1982 which has been introduced to provide emergency provisions so that in the event of a threatened interruption to the power supply in the Capital Territory steps can be taken to ensure proper and the best usage of electricity. It provides for notice to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. It indicates that the Minister for the Capital Territory can gazette a period not to exceed 28 days. It further provides that in the event that the situation changes it can be revoked. I think it is regrettable that it is necessary. But I think what we have seen in the last couple of weeks indicates that this sort of legislation needs to be available in the Australian Capital Territory. Questions have been raised about the civil liberties aspect of the Bill. I agree also that there is provision for the granting of a warrant. I think there is adequate provision in that respect. Penalties are provided in the amount of $2,000 for an individual and $10,000 for a corporate body which may breach the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1929 the Australian Capital Territory has purchased electricity from New South Wales both as electricity and in connection with power transmission. The price paid is fixed, I think, on an annual basis. There have been very few problems over the years. In 1975 there was some difficulty, but we have had to face difficulties since June 1981. I think the requests for cutbacks in the Australian Capital Territory, then and recently, have been quite successful. I believe that if there were to be problems this winter requests for cutbacks would be quite successful. But I think it is necessary, in view of the serious problems which have arisen, that this legislation should be available to see that electricity is best used. About 60 per cent of our power comes directly from New South Wales. The 40 per cent of electricity that comes from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority also, of course, comes to us through the New South Wales transmission system.

There have been suggestions that the Commonwealth should, in a sense, demand more of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. I wish briefly to refer to that aspect of the matter and to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949. I think it is worth referring to some aspects of it. The Bill, in the preamble says, amongst other things:
AND WHEREAS it is desirable that provision should be made now to enable increased supplies of electricity to be immediately available in time of war:
Of course, we hope that that is not a matter to which we are referring. The next paragraph states:

And whereas the consumption of electricity in the Australian Capital Territory and, in particular, at the Seat of Government within that Territory, is increasing and is likely to continue to increase:

Of course, it has. The population of Canberra is very much larger now than it could have been envisaged in 1949. Section 4 of the Act provides for an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States of New South Wales and Victoria. The agreement, which is a schedule to the Act, is a part of the Act. It has been approved and incorporated as part of the Act and sets out the actual arrangements which operate. Section 16 of the Act states:
(1) The functions of the Authority are-

(a) with the object of assisting to ensure that adequate supplies of electricity are available, in time of war as well as in time of peace, in the States of New South Wales and Victoria and in the Australian Capital Territory for purposes necessary or conducive to the defence of the Commonwealth and for other purposes of the Commonwealth, to provide hydro-electric works in the Snowy Mountains Area for the generation of electricity;

The Schedule deals in some detail with the functioning and running of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. Part V of Schedule 1, which relates to generation and supply of electricity, provides for the Commonwealth, during construction, to declare the amount of electricity it would want from each stage of development. It makes provision for the Commonwealth's reservation to be notified to the Authority. Subsequently it provides that the balance be divided two-thirds for the State of New South Wales and one-third for the State of Victoria. The Schedule very clearly indicates that if the Commonwealth wished to change the amount that it received, it would have to be agreed by Victoria and New South Wales. That is a problem that may take some time to solve. I think it is unlikely that either of the States concerned would want to interfere with the agreement as it stands. In addition, New South Wales has provided the balance of the electricity which the Australian Capital Territory has needed over the years . I think to talk about changing the Schedule to the Snowy Mountains Hydro- electric Power Act is, perhaps, embarking upon something which may not be in the best interests of anyone involved, particularly the Australian Capital Territory .

As I said at the beginning of my speech, the transmission of electricity to the Australian Capital Territory comes entirely on power lines provided by New South Wales. In a sense, I suppose, one could say that they are leased. If the Commonwealth thought it could take more of the Snowy electricity and provide its own transmission lines, the cost would be a great deal more. It would be something that could not really be justified when the other facility is, in fact , available. Basically, what I am saying is that it is an economically sound system that has exhibited sensible planning and worked well. For that reason, I think that for the Australian Capital Territory, in a sense to change it unilaterally is something that could not be achieved and may, in fact, leave us particularly vulnerable. If there were industrial trouble in the Snowy Mountains area, the Australian Capital Territory could be very much at the mercy of New South Wales and left without power. If New South Wales cut off the transmission supplies we again would be extremely vulnerable. These are perhaps rather far- fetched propositions, but I think we need to look at the situation in totality.

While there can be absolutely no doubt that it is most regrettable that the management of the New South Wales system has in recent times been such as to cause the situation which we have seen recently, it would not be prudent for us to embark on the course which some have proposed, namely, demanding that the Commonwealth insist upon a greater share of the hydro-electric power supply. In fact, that power supply boosts the peak needs in the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and presumably Victoria. There is no reason for that situation to be changed as long as we can still get the power that we need. In the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on Energy Use, Distribution and Conservation in the Australian Capital Territory some reference was made to the question of electric supply. Recommendation No. 4 stated:
The Committee recommends that the ACTEA conduct a survey of the generating equipment within the ACT with a view to establishing whether or not there are adequate emergency facilities within the ACT.

As yet the Government has not responded to this report. Events of the last couple of weeks indicate that a fairly early response to this report should be given. I urge that this recommendation be implemented so that we know what is available in the Australian Capital Territory and what emergency facilities we can look to in the event of there being a crisis. It comes into the category of at least trying to help ourselves to the greatest extent possible. I hope that the industrial troubles and other problems which are plaguing the New South Wales system will be overcome and that the management of the facilities will be such that these problems will not arise during this winter. I believe that Mr Wran has said that the crisis should last for not more than 12 months. In a climate such as Canberra has that could mean an extremely cold winter, especially for old people or people who are invalid and somewhat restricted to their homes. It may well be that we need the emergency provisions which are provided for in the Bill which we are discussing tonight. I certainly hope that it will not be necessary for them to be used. I commend to the Senate that the legislation be passed so that it can be available if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the adjournment debate to refer again to the problems of Vietnam veterans and their attempt to obtain justice for the injuries and illnesses they have suffered as a result of their service in Vietnam. Last Thursday in another place a matter of public importance was raised by my colleague, Mr Holding. He made an appeal to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for the judicial inquiry requested more than two and a half years ago by the Vietnam Veterans Association. It is unfortunate that my colleague's appeal to the Prime Minister was ignored. He handed over the responsibility of replying to that appeal to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson). I will say more about that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Australian and other forces invaded Vietnam a series of illnesses has beset those people. Most of them apparently have been caused by the types of defoliants and chemicals that were used there. The United States of America became alarmed at some of the results as far back as 1969 when it ceased the use of dangerous defoliants. However that decision was not taken in relation to the Australian troops and the areas in which they operated. Much of the responsibility for this must fall on the present Prime Minister who, at that time, was the Minister for Defence. He was the Minister for Defence from November 1969 to March 1971. It appears that Australian troops were still using these types of defoliants as late as 1971 and possibly until the early part of 1972.

Almost every ex-service organisation in Australia has backed the Vietnam Veterans Association in its call for a judicial inquiry. Incidentally, this includes large sections of the Returned Services League. Only the RSL hierarchy has strongly supported the Government in rejecting it. The Legion of Ex- servicemen and Women, the second largest ex-services body in Australia, has consistently backed the setting up of a judicial inquiry right from the start. However, the Government has planted its feet firmly on the ground and said no. After much beating of breasts and much beating of drums, the Government did set up an epidemiological survey. At the time we said it was too little too late and that it did not do the job for which it was established. The Minister and the Government have come to realise that it did not do the job. The survey has now been abolished. One of the strange things is that when the Minister representing Senator Messner in another place replied to statements made by Opposition speakers he apparently did not know that the study had been abolished. The result was a very lengthy Press statement released by Phill Thompson, the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association. I agree with everything that is contained in it. Mr Deputy President, I have shown it to your predecessor and to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and both have agreed to its incorporation in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRESS RELEASE FROM THE VIETNAM VETERANS ASSOCIATION OF AUSTRALIA
The Vietnam Veterans Association is extremely disappointed that the Prime Minister was not prepared to answer personally the charges made against him in the Parliament last Thursday.
The response for the Government to those charges by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr David Thomson, was totally inadequate and factually wrong.
Some examples of his wrong statements are:

1. The Minister said only the VVAA supports the judicial inquiry, among ex- service organisations. We wish to point out to the Minister that, on 11 August, 1981, at an RSL-convened conference in Canberra, 27 out of 28 ex-service organisations present (including the Korea and South East Asian Forces Association) voted to support an independent judicial inquiry. That inquiry has also been supported by the Senate, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Labor Party and the Democrats, among others.

2. The Minister said that the RSL has not called for a judicial inquiry. In May , 1980, the RSL N.S.W. State Congresss voted, by 499 to 1, to support a judicial inquiry. The N.S.W. Branch represents about half the RSL membership. This decision was put before the RSL National Executive by Sir Colin Hines, N.S.W. President, on 7 September, 1980. It was not voted on because of statements made to that meeting by Sir William Keys, RSL National President. Sir Colin Hines said in 'Reveille' (March/April, 1981, Vol. 56, No. 2) that he had been overruled. A statement was made to that meeting by Major-General (retired) D. Vincent, who was Commander, Armed Forces, Vietnam, 1967-68, that he knew the chemicals were dangerous, but he was acting under Government instructions in ordering their use by Australian forces, and that he did not realise the full extent of the dangers until 1980.

3. The Minister said that the Government had initiated a program of epidemiological studies. He is apparently unaware that his own Ministerial colleague, the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Senator Messner, announced on 15 February, 1982, that the Government had scrapped the major study.

4. The Minister said that Government Departments are co-operating fully with the current inquiry being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and Environment. Having discussed that inquiry at great length with the Committee and their Secretariat, I can quite categorically state that Committee Members have expressed considerable concern at the lack of co-operation they have had from all of the Government Departments involved (Veterans Affairs, Health and Defence).

5. The Minister said that the VVAA does not represent Vietnam veterans. Without the VVAA, the RSL would not have done anything about our claims, there would be no Senate Committee inquiry, no government-sponsored studies, no counselling centres and no public concern.

6. The Minister said only 63 veterans had visited counselling centres in Sydney and Adelaide since they were established. Our information is that those centres have had over 340 clients, and are having trouble handling the workload. Already they are seeking more staff. On 16 July, 1981, at a meeting in Canberra with the Minister for Veterans Affairs and his senior advisers, we proposed the type of counselling service which we believe was and is necessary. The Minister refused to accept our submission and established a much more limited service. Even though the current service is so limited, the already demonstrated level of demand indicates the problems that Vietnam veterans are experiencing, along with the effects of those problems on our families. In a recent article the Sydney Morning Herald reported that the Adelaide Counselling Service alone was receiving 10 clients a day.

7. The Minister quoted two scientific reports as evidence for the Government's case that the chemicals were not linked with the long term illnesses now suffered by Vietnam veterans. The Government-appointed Repatriation Review Tribunal, in its 'Reasons for Decision' in the recent Simpson case, found that there was sufficient evidence of these links to award a pension to Mrs Simpson. It should be noted that, in that case, the RRT only considered evidence about the US dispersal of defoliants, and only phenoxyacetic herbicides at that, and did not consider other evidence of the use of chemicals by Australian forces. We have long pointed out, on the public record, our concern about both US and Australian forces' use of both arsenic-based Agent Blue and the organophosphate insecticide, Malathion. Has Mr Thomson personally read the 1967 Midwest Institute report which is quoted in the Parliament? Apparently not, for he would have found, for example, the following statement:

''Arsenicals, particularly the trivalent forms of arsenic, have long been regarded as either carcinogens or possibly as co-carcinogens. In either case there is reason to be wary of the widespread distribution of these materials until evidence of their long-term safety under the conditions of use has been obtained.'' (Assessment of Ecological Effects of Extensive or Repeated Use of Herbicides, Midwest Research Institute, 1967, pp. 163, 164).

8. The Minister said that the chemicals used in Vietnam were, and still are, commercially available and used within Australia. There is a wealth of public evidence that most of the chemicals used in Vietnam were not of the same composition as those used in Australia, the US, and elsewhere, at the time or since. As the Minister should know, both because of his own military experience and his responsibilities as a Minister of the Crown, peacetime precautions often cannot be followed in wartime. The Government's own report, ''Pesticides Used In Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study ,'' says: ''Once again, however, it must be stressed that difficulties are encountered during conditions of war which prevent the rigid adoption of precautions that can be applied in peacetime . . . Although the regulations were designed to protect personnel from potential adverse health effects, it is impossible to determine the extent to which they were met.'' (p. 32).

9. The Minister defended strongly the public servants in the Department of Veterans Affairs. The real problem, for Vietnam veterans, is the attitudes of most of the senior management in the DVA. We are not critical of DVA junior staff who are restricted by these attitudes, and who in any case do not make major decisions. The appearances of the Vietnam Special Studies Group personnel from the DVA before the Senate Committee's inquiry have been less than impressive. My Association is concerned also at the recent speech made by the DVA Permanent Head, Mr D. Volker, where he foreshadowed major legislative and administrative changes to the repatriation system.

In summary then, we are very concerned that the Government has still not examined the detailed evidence which we believe supports our claims. We are forced to repeat, yet again, our call for a judicial inquiry, outside the political arena, which can impartially assess that evidence.
We are also disappointed that, despite mounting evidence in support of our claims, the Government's attitude to our problems is the same as it was over two years ago.

That is something of which we could never, in the same context, accuse Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, Senator Chaney or the present Government when we look at the publicity budget that is devoted to social security recipients in this country. The Minister for Social Security, and everyone else in the Parliament, knows that the only person who he is trying to help by this outburst of publicity in the electronic media at the moment is Lindsay Thompson, the lame duck Premier of Victoria.

What I have said follows what I said in my speech on the adjournment last week about that other exercise in government futility, the petulant action of the Minister in standing down hundreds of officers of his own Department and then spending $360,000 in the newspapers to justify his actions. As a result, he caused chaos amongst innocent claimants for pensions and benefits. I feel that I must make an explanation concerning figures that I quoted during that speech of a week ago.

I said then that I believed the sum that had been wasted by the Minister and the Government in that futile exercise was just over a million dollars. I have learnt, from an answer supplied to me today by the Minister, that in fact the figure was half a million dollars low. Senator Chaney spent more than a million and a half dollars of the taxpayers' money in running down departmental morale and causing untold distress to welfare groups and the welfare clients of his Department. As at 1 March 1982, in addition to the $361,000 expended upon advertising, he had reimbursed the New South Wales Government and voluntary agencies to the tune of $1,160,525 or $1,522,315 all told. Therefore, I apologise to the Senate for underestimating the cost of Senator Chaney's bull-in -a-china-shop approach by more than half a million dollars. The Government should be condemned for wasting the taxpayers' money upon such self-justified propaganda. Equally, it should be condemned for its refusal to inform the poorer people of their rights.
I propose to cite two more extracts from what was said by the Task Force on Departmental Information. The first is:
Reaching the disadvantaged effectively costs more than reaching the general public . . .
But the Government has shown quite clearly that it is not willing to spend money to reach such people. The second extract is:
Among Government officials especially we detected a fear that people would ' take advantage' of the services offered if they were publicised 'too widely'.

In other words, we have the Government and some bureaucrats claiming that they will not publicise benefits or services available to the disadvantaged because of a fear that they may actually take advantage of their rights under the legislation of this Parliament. In contrast, they are quite happy to publicise to a considerable degree a program which is aimed at middle class voters, who they fear during the Victorian election campaign are drifting away from them. We know, of course, that this will not save the Victorian Government. This expenditure is as useless as that of Senator Chaney during the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association dispute.

I make no apologies for raising this matter, in Senator Chaney's terms, in the dead of night as the adjournment debate is the most appropriate time to draw the attention-as I did last week, as I do this week and as I will do in any future week-of the Senate and of the public of this country to the fact that this Government, which preaches economic restraint and says that it will cut Budgets, is only too willing, for cheap electoral purposes, to spend a considerable amount of money in the electronic media and in the newspapers when it thinks it will win votes, but it is not willing to do so to inform people of their rights and in fact continues to use old-fashioned and what it admits are ineffective methods of publicising those benefits which always go to the most disadvantaged members of our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Grimes, make no apologies for raising this matter in the adjournment debate tonight. I fully support the remarks of Senator Grimes. I think he ought to be complimented for drawing the attention of the Senate to what the Government has engaged in today; that is, a form of public funding of elections. It announced in the other place today that it will extend $300,000 of taxpayers' money to endeavour to explain to the many home owners who are seriously disadvantaged because of high interest rates in this country just how this home loan package will operate.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us will recall during the 1977 election those full page advertisements which appeared in the daily Press in Australia depicting a person with a fistful of $5 notes. That might have been paid for by the Liberal Party. But then we all recall that in the 1978 autumn session of the Parliament the Taxation Office was instructed to place advertisements explaining to the people the reasons for the Government not giving back to the people a handful of $5 notes but in fact imposing upon them an extra income tax surcharge. We were able to flesh out during the Estimates hearings the fact that it was the first time ever that the Taxation Office of Australia had to carry out public advertisements at the behest of a government to explain why it was imposing an income tax surcharge on the taxpayers of Australia after having, just a few months prior to that, told the people that if they voted for the Liberal Party they would receive in return a fistful of $5 notes. That did not happen.

Now we see a repeat of that waste of taxpayers' money. The Government is trying to get itself off the hook and is trying to explain why it imposed the extra surcharge on the taxpayers of this country. I talk about the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, not the big taxpayers who have all the lurks in the world available by which to evade income tax. I talk about the people who have their income deducted from their pay packet every week or, like public servants and members of parliament, every fortnight. When we get our pay cheque our income tax has been deducted and we have no way of evading tax at all. The big taxpayers can employ highly skilled lawyers to evade paying the income tax that they should pay. I will not delay the Senate any longer except to say that the Government, despite the fact that it is opposed to public funding of elections, blatantly admitted in the House of Representatives today that it will expend $300,000 of taxpayers' money to get its story across and to try to tell the people what is in it for some of them with regard to this home loan package.

Of course we all know that whilst some people might be advantaged by what the Government is offering, more people will be disadvantaged because at this time they have to pay an extra one per cent in interest on their home loan. We are well aware that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Bill Hayden, said that before the end of the financial year people will incur another one per cent interest rate rise. It is anybody's guess what the rate will be by the end of the year. It could be, as the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, has said, that people who are encumbered with home loans from banks and lending institutions will pay interest at the rate of 18 per cent. No wonder the Government today is going to expend $300,000 of taxpayers' money trying to get itself off the hook. It is in a situation which it has created and it cannot blame anybody else for it. It is just purely mismanagement of the economy of this country. I join with Senator Grimes in rising tonight and saying that the Government deserves to be criticised most strongly for the actions it has taken in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the reasons why there is so much proportionately-I think this was a point that Senator Grimes raised-being spent in Victoria compared with New South Wales , it is pertinent to realise that the costs of television advertising on Melbourne media are substantially greater per unit than those of advertising on the equivalent Sydney media. TALK.START.PARA: —There is no election in New South Wales at present.
—If Senator McLaren would only listen occasionally, he would learn something.
—Not from the present instructor. It is a valiant effort, though.

—It would be pretty hard to teach him anything, I must agree. We will have another go tomorrow night. He should try it again at Question Time tomorrow. SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the points raised by Senator Keeffe concerning Vietnam veterans, whilst I would prefer to speak at greater length on these matters during the debate on the forthcoming Repatriation Amendment Bill, which will be in the Senate in the next week or two--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give me a dry run tonight.

—I do not really want to keep the honourable senator here all night. The point about it is that having seen the document the honourable senator incorporated in Hansard, which I understand is substantially a Press statement attributed to the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, Mr Phill Thompson, and which I understand emanated from the office of Mr Clyde Holding in this Parliament House-if it did not, it certainly was delivered to my office from there this morning-I think several things should be said about it. Clearly there are a number of matters--

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I submit that the Minister is making an unfair inference in saying that the Press release did not come from the Vietnam Veterans Association. I assure him that it came from that Association. It is a quite wrong inference to say that it emanated from someone' s office in this building. Things come out on behalf of various other organisations from offices of members of the Liberal Party. I do not take any exception to that if they have the facilities for distribution. The statement was made by the very worthy President of the Vietnam Veterans Association.
—Senator Keeffe has made his point. There is no point of order.

—The only answer I give on that point of order is simply that Mr Phill Thompson is in continuous contact with my office. He knows where it is. I was surprised that I did not receive a copy of the Press release from him directly and that rather it came from Mr Clyde Holding's office. I find that somewhat unusual.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should understand that, of a total number of veterans who returned from the Vietnam war of 45,000 or thereabouts, the Vietnam Veterans Association speaks, we understand, for a few thousand-probably fewer than 3,000. Eight thousand Vietnam veterans are members of the Returned Services League. Many are members of quite separate battalion and regiment associations. The Vietnam Veterans Association is not the sole source of information about the problems of Vietnam veterans which come to governments. Consequently, this Government has to consider all interests in this regard and take into account the statements of all people in relation to the problems of Vietnam veterans. As I said earlier, I would prefer to deal with many of the detailed matters which were raised in the Press statement in greater detail when we come to debate the repatriation legislation. Suffice it to say that many of the statements in the Press release are erroneous and obviously slanted to present one point of view. They take account of pedantic differences in wording made by individuals over a period. If that is the kind of debate to which this matter has now descended I am sorry. It does not say much for the Vietnam Veterans Association or for any other group which is trying to promote a very worthwhile cause.

I conclude by saying that the Government's interests in this matter are quite clear and have been made so over the last 15 or 18 months. It has to find answers to the herbicide question, provide treatment for those who need it, invite people into the repatriation system, test their eligibility for compensation and see whether it can solve the problems which, in many cases, are manifest. Senator Keeffe knows clearly this Government's policy and this Minister's policy in that respect. We are seeking, through those various means and through the establishment particularly of free treatment of people in urgent need and counselling centres in each capital city in Australia to assist those who have a very real need. To reduce the debate to this level is beyond all the pales that might be introduced into this place. I believe it reflects badly on those who seek to make a political issue out of the misfortune of veterans.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) produce a summary report on Television Advertising of Foods Directed to Children.
(2) Did any discussions take place between the NHMRC and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) before the terms of reference of the inquiry were drawn up.

(3) Is it the responsibility of the ABT under the terms of the Broadcasting and Television Act to set standards for national advertising on commercial radio and television; if so, why was not the ABT considered to be the appropriate body to conduct the inquiry.
(4) What action has been or is being taken to implement the recommendations of the NHMRC report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Summary Report of the Working Party on Television Advertising of Foods Directed to Children was endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) at its 90th Session, October 1980. At the Council's 92nd Session in October 1981 the full Report of the Working Party was endorsed.

(2) and (3) While no discussions took place between the NHMRC and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal prior to the establishment of the Working Party , the intention of the Council to take action in response to Recommendation 12. 50 of the Report 'Children and Television' from the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, and conduct the inquiry, was conveyed in a letter from My Department to the then Postal and Telecommunications Department.

The establishment of the Working Party is consistent with the NHMRC's charter to inquire into, advise and make recommendations to the Commonwealth and the States on matters of public health legislation and administration and on any other matters relating to health, medical and dental care and medical research.

The question of food advertising had been a concern to the Council's Nutrition (Standing) Committee since 1973 and, while the Working Party was established partly as a response to the Senate Standing Committee's recommendation, its establishment was also as a consequence of expressions of the community and professional concern in the matter. As well, expert committees within the NHMRC had been considering, concurrently with the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee, the question of potential problems arising from advertising-directed to children-of certain categories of foods.

Since the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-under the terms of the Broadcasting and Television Act-is responsible for broadcasting standards throughout Australia, arrangements were made for the Tribunal to be represented on the Working Party. However, the major consideration of the inquiry was related to the nutritional, dental and other health consequences of food advertising. The subject of the inquiry was within the ambit and competence of the NHMRC.

(4) As regards implementation of the Working Party's recommendations, the proposals have been referred to State and Territory health and education authorities, industry and professional organisations for consideration. Recommendations relating to nutrition education and research are presently under consideration. Also, the NHMRC has endorsed the establishment of a Working Party -comprising representatives of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the advertising and television industries-to develop guidelines for television advertisements for children.

In response to a recommendation from the Working Party that information on the constituents and nutrient composition of new foods entering the market place be published, the NHMRC is currently funding a food analytical program to provide data on the nutrient composition of Australian foods.
Broadly, the Recommendations of the Working Party reflect the Government's present policy favouring industry self-regulation as regards advertising practices.
