TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February 1982 (Hansard, page 79) Senator Siddons asked me , as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister assure the House that after the recent experience of HMAS Sydney and the earlier experience of the United States Navy with the United States ship Belknap that the Government will not order warships which have aluminium in their structures? Is it true that if HMAS Sydney had not been constructed largely of aluminium the main deck would not have warped and the damage would not have been nearly so extensive? Do both Royal Canadian Navy and the British Navy refuse to use aluminium in their ships because of the vulnerability of this material to fire?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The susceptibility of aluminium in a major fire is recognised and was well demonstrated in the fire on the USS Belknap in 1975. As a consequence of the Belknap experience the aluminium superstructure, above the steel main deck, in the FFG-7 Oliver Hazard Perry Class design is divided into three discrete fire zones, each zone being separated by fire insulation material attached to the aluminium bulkhead at the zone boundary.

Fire detectors are also installed in these ships, and a fire such as that on HMAS Sydney would have been detected earlier had the ship been completed and in service and not unmanned as it was at the builder's yard.

Ship design is a compromise of many conflicting requirements. Whilst the disadvantages of the use of aluminium in warships are recognised, its high strength to weight ratio make it a desirable construction material, particularly where weight savings are required. I am not able to give an unequivocal assurance that the Government would not order in the future warships with aluminium in their structure.

The main deck of HMAS Sydney is constructed mainly of steel and there is no indication that this deck has 'warped', however, portions of the aluminium structure above the main deck (01 deck) were buckled in some places as a consequence of the fire.
Aluminium superstructures have been used on British Navy warships; however it is understood that both the British and Canadian Navies do not favour the use of aluminium.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 476) Senator Crichton-Browne asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources questions without notice about various aspects of the mining, marketing and processing of diamonds by the Ashton Joint Venture.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following additional information to that provided at the time:

The Commonwealth Government recognises the sovereignty of the Western Australian Government in regard to development agreements for major mining projects in Western Australia and does not intend to interfere in the comprehensive agreement that has been entered into between the Western Australian Government and the Ashton Joint Venture partners. That agreement provides, inter alia, for independent valuation and approval of marketing arrangements by the Western Australian Government but no proposals have yet been presented by the partners.

However, the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to ensure that the national interest is protected and, in exercising that responsibility, must be able to take whatever action it considers necessary. This is why no firm undertaking can be given that control over the export of diamonds will not be introduced although I reiterate that there is no present intention to do so.

With regard to the more general question about export controls which the honourable senator asked on 25 February, the purpose of the export controls on certain minerals is to safeguard Australia's national interests and, in particular, to ensure that Australia receives fair and reasonable returns for the exports of those minerals. These objectives are being achieved although no specific example can be provided because the Government has undertaken to the mineral exporting companies concerned that all aspects of its consultations with them and of contract negotiations will be kept confidential.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 477) Senator Tate asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources a question without notice about diamonds and I undertook to seek information on one aspect concerning the role of the proposed Commonwealth valuer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Trade and Resources has supplied the following supplementary information:

As he has stated, he sees it as necessary, in order to carry out the Commonwealth Government's responsibility of ensuring that the national interest is safeguarded, that there should be a Commonwealth valuer who would periodically check the value of diamonds being exported. However, it is not possible to indicate what arrangements might be put in place, including the role of a Commonwealth valuer because the Ashton Joint Venture has not yet decided how Argyle diamonds will be marketed when production commences later this year.
